                         {
                              "title": "AbortController TypeError.",
                              "description": "Hi,\r\nI was getting the following error when trying to use this uploadLink with my apollo client:\r\n`TypeError: 'abort' called on an object that does not implement interface AbortController.`\r\n\r\nHere is my apollo client code:\r\n```\r\nimport { ApolloClient } from 'apollo-client';\r\nimport { createUploadLink } from './apollo-upload-link';\r\nimport { setContext } from 'apollo-link-context';\r\nimport { InMemoryCache } from 'apollo-cache-inmemory';\r\nimport { persistCache } from 'apollo-cache-persist';\r\n\r\nconst authLink = setContext((_, { headers }) => {\r\n  // get the authentication token from session storage if it exists\r\n  const token = window.sessionStorage.getItem('token');\r\n  // return the headers to the context so httpLink can read them\r\n  return {\r\n    headers: {\r\n      ...headers,\r\n      authorization: token ? token : '',\r\n    },\r\n  };\r\n});\r\n\r\nconst uploadLink = createUploadLink({\r\n  uri: `${process.env.REACT_APP_BACKEND_URL}/graphql`,\r\n});\r\n\r\n// Custom InMemoryCache to remove __typename from 'id' variables, because I\r\n// already do this server side.\r\nconst cache = new InMemoryCache({\r\n  dataIdFromObject: o => o.id || null,\r\n});\r\n\r\npersistCache({\r\n  cache,\r\n  storage: sessionStorage,\r\n});\r\n\r\nconst client = new ApolloClient({\r\n  // By default, this client will send queries to the\r\n  //  `/graphql` endpoint on the same host\r\n  link: authLink.concat(uploadLink),\r\n  cache,\r\n});\r\n\r\nexport default client;\r\n```\r\n\r\nI fixed the error by merging code from [apollo-link-http](https://github.com/apollographql/apollo-link/blob/master/packages/apollo-link-http/src/httpLink.ts) with the code from `apollo-upload-client`. Here's what I got:\r\n\r\n```\r\nimport { ApolloLink, Observable, fromError } from 'apollo-link';\r\nimport {\r\n  serializeFetchParameter,\r\n  selectURI,\r\n  parseAndCheckHttpResponse,\r\n  checkFetcher,\r\n  selectHttpOptionsAndBody,\r\n  createSignalIfSupported,\r\n  fallbackHttpConfig,\r\n  UriFunction as _UriFunction,\r\n} from 'apollo-link-http-common';\r\nimport extractFiles from 'extract-files';\r\n\r\nexport { ReactNativeFile } from 'extract-files';\r\n\r\nexport const createUploadLink = (linkOptions = {}) => {\r\n  let {\r\n    uri: fetchUri = '/graphql',\r\n    // use default global fetch if nothing passed in\r\n    credentials,\r\n    fetch: fetcher,\r\n    fetchOptions,\r\n    headers,\r\n    includeExtensions,\r\n    useGETForQueries,\r\n  } = linkOptions;\r\n\r\n  // dev warnings to ensure fetch is present\r\n  checkFetcher(fetcher);\r\n\r\n  // fetcher is set here rather than the destructuring to ensure fetch is\r\n  // declared before referencing it. Reference in the destructuring would cause a\r\n  // ReferenceError\r\n  if (!fetcher) {\r\n    fetcher = fetch;\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  const linkConfig = {\r\n    http: { includeExtensions },\r\n    options: fetchOptions,\r\n    credentials,\r\n    headers,\r\n  };\r\n\r\n  return new ApolloLink(operation => {\r\n    let chosenURI = selectURI(operation, fetchUri);\r\n\r\n    const context = operation.getContext();\r\n\r\n    const contextConfig = {\r\n      http: context.http,\r\n      options: context.fetchOptions,\r\n      credentials: context.credentials,\r\n      headers: context.headers,\r\n    };\r\n\r\n    // uses fallback, link, and then context to build options\r\n    const { options, body } = selectHttpOptionsAndBody(\r\n      operation,\r\n      fallbackHttpConfig,\r\n      linkConfig,\r\n      contextConfig,\r\n    );\r\n\r\n    const { controller, signal } = createSignalIfSupported();\r\n    if (controller) options.signal = signal;\r\n\r\n    // If requested, set method to GET if there are no mutations.\r\n    const definitionIsMutation = d => {\r\n      return d.kind === 'OperationDefinition' && d.operation === 'mutation';\r\n    };\r\n    if (\r\n      useGETForQueries &&\r\n      !operation.query.definitions.some(definitionIsMutation)\r\n    ) {\r\n      options.method = 'GET';\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    if (options.method === 'GET') {\r\n      const { newURI, parseError } = rewriteURIForGET(chosenURI, body);\r\n      if (parseError) {\r\n        return fromError(parseError);\r\n      }\r\n      chosenURI = newURI;\r\n    } else {\r\n      try {\r\n        options.body = serializeFetchParameter(body, 'Payload');\r\n      } catch (parseError) {\r\n        return fromError(parseError);\r\n      }\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    const files = extractFiles(body);\r\n\r\n    // If we are sending files in the body of the request\r\n    if (files.length !== 0) {\r\n      // Automatically set by fetch when the body is a FormData instance.\r\n      delete options.headers['content-type'];\r\n\r\n      // GraphQL multipart request spec:\r\n      // https://github.com/jaydenseric/graphql-multipart-request-spec\r\n      options.body = new FormData();\r\n      options.body.append('operations', serializeFetchParameter(body));\r\n      options.body.append(\r\n        'map',\r\n        JSON.stringify(\r\n          files.reduce((map, { path }, index) => {\r\n            map[`${index}`] = [path];\r\n            return map;\r\n          }, {}),\r\n        ),\r\n      );\r\n      files.forEach(({ file }, index) =>\r\n        options.body.append(index, file, file.name),\r\n      );\r\n    } else options.body = serializeFetchParameter(body);\r\n\r\n    return new Observable(observer => {\r\n      fetcher(chosenURI, options)\r\n        .then(response => {\r\n          // Forward the response on the context.\r\n          operation.setContext({ response });\r\n          return response;\r\n        })\r\n        .then(parseAndCheckHttpResponse(operation))\r\n        .then(result => {\r\n          observer.next(result);\r\n          observer.complete();\r\n          return result;\r\n        })\r\n        .catch(err => {\r\n          // fetch was cancelled so its already been cleaned up in the\r\n          // unsubscribe\r\n          if (err.name === 'AbortError') return;\r\n          // if it is a network error, BUT there is graphql result info\r\n          // fire the next observer before calling error\r\n          // this gives apollo-client (and react-apollo) the `graphqlErrors` and\r\n          // `networkErrors` to pass to UI\r\n          if (err.result && err.result.errors)\r\n            // if we dont' call next, the UI can only show networkError because AC didn't\r\n            // get andy graphqlErrors\r\n            // this is graphql execution result info (i.e errors and possibly data)\r\n            // this is because there is no formal spec how errors should translate to\r\n            // http status codes. So an auth error (401) could have both data\r\n            // from a public field, errors from a private field, and a status of 401\r\n            // {\r\n            //  user { // this will have errors\r\n            //    firstName\r\n            //  }\r\n            //  products { // this is public so will have data\r\n            //    cost\r\n            //  }\r\n            // }\r\n            //\r\n            // the result of above *could* look like this:\r\n            // {\r\n            //   data: { products: [{ cost: \"$10\" }] },\r\n            //   errors: [{\r\n            //      message: 'your session has timed out',\r\n            //      path: []\r\n            //   }]\r\n            // }\r\n            // status code of above would be a 401\r\n            // in the UI you want to show data where you can, errors as data where you can\r\n            // and use correct http status codes\r\n            observer.next(err.result);\r\n\r\n          observer.error(err);\r\n        });\r\n\r\n      return () => {\r\n        // Abort fetch as the optional cleanup function.\r\n        if (controller) return controller.abort;\r\n      };\r\n    });\r\n  });\r\n};\r\n\r\n// For GET operations, returns the given URI rewritten with parameters, or a\r\n// parse error.\r\nfunction rewriteURIForGET(chosenURI, body) {\r\n  // Implement the standard HTTP GET serialization, plus 'extensions'. Note\r\n  // the extra level of JSON serialization!\r\n  const queryParams = [];\r\n  const addQueryParam = (key, value) => {\r\n    queryParams.push(`${key}=${encodeURIComponent(value)}`);\r\n  };\r\n\r\n  if ('query' in body) {\r\n    addQueryParam('query', body.query);\r\n  }\r\n  if (body.operationName) {\r\n    addQueryParam('operationName', body.operationName);\r\n  }\r\n  if (body.variables) {\r\n    let serializedVariables;\r\n    try {\r\n      serializedVariables = serializeFetchParameter(\r\n        body.variables,\r\n        'Variables map',\r\n      );\r\n    } catch (parseError) {\r\n      return { parseError };\r\n    }\r\n    addQueryParam('variables', serializedVariables);\r\n  }\r\n  if (body.extensions) {\r\n    let serializedExtensions;\r\n    try {\r\n      serializedExtensions = serializeFetchParameter(\r\n        body.extensions,\r\n        'Extensions map',\r\n      );\r\n    } catch (parseError) {\r\n      return { parseError };\r\n    }\r\n    addQueryParam('extensions', serializedExtensions);\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  // Reconstruct the URI with added query params.\r\n  // XXX This assumes that the URI is well-formed and that it doesn't\r\n  //     already contain any of these query params. We could instead use the\r\n  //     URL API and take a polyfill (whatwg-url@6) for older browsers that\r\n  //     don't support URLSearchParams. Note that some browsers (and\r\n  //     versions of whatwg-url) support URL but not URLSearchParams!\r\n  let fragment = '',\r\n    preFragment = chosenURI;\r\n  const fragmentStart = chosenURI.indexOf('#');\r\n  if (fragmentStart !== -1) {\r\n    fragment = chosenURI.substr(fragmentStart);\r\n    preFragment = chosenURI.substr(0, fragmentStart);\r\n  }\r\n  const queryParamsPrefix = preFragment.indexOf('?') === -1 ? '?' : '&';\r\n  const newURI =\r\n    preFragment + queryParamsPrefix + queryParams.join('&') + fragment;\r\n  return { newURI };\r\n}\r\n\r\nexport class UploadLink extends ApolloLink {\r\n  requester;\r\n  constructor(opts) {\r\n    super(createUploadLink(opts).request);\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nMost of the changes probably aren't needed, but it's working and I don't want to mess with it at the moment. The key changes - I think - are the following: \r\n```\r\nreturn () => {\r\n  // Abort fetch as the optional cleanup function.\r\n  if (controller) return controller.abort;\r\n};\r\n```\r\nIt wasn't returning a function before, now it is.\r\n```\r\nconst { controller, signal } = createSignalIfSupported();\r\nif (controller) options.signal = signal;\r\n```\r\nI moved this out of the Observable.\r\n\r\nI haven't done any formal testing, but it's working for me know. Just thought I'd let you know. :+1: ",

                              "title": "Files created with the window.File constructor upload empty in Safari",
                              "description": "This is a fun issue! Mostly because I can't seem to pinpoint where the issue exactly lies! 😄 \r\n\r\n### Scenario\r\nI use the apollo-upload-client together with the apollo-upload-server in my React project to upload images to my server. I use some simple client-side image compression to reduce the size of the file to upload to speed up the upload process (greatly outweighs the time required to compress the image + lowers data usage).\r\n\r\nIn Chrome and Firefox the upload works like a charm with compressed images. 👍 \r\n\r\n### Problem\r\nIn Safari my client doesn't correctly upload the compressed image: the Upload promise on the server resolves to a FileStream with a length of 0. 👎 My Request Headers **Content-Length** is way to small to include the image, so it's simply not being sent, though **no errors** are being thrown. I do get the metadata of the image (filename, mime type etc.) on the server so the request is correctly being sent, it just doesn't contain the image data.\r\n\r\n### Expected behaviour\r\nThe image would correctly be sent OR an error would be thrown telling me if something's wrong.\r\n\r\n### Root of problem\r\nThe obvious issue is that I'm breaking my image during compression. However, when I `console.log(URL.createObjectURL(myImage))` and copy/paste that string in an `<img>` tag on the page, it renders correctly and when logging the file itself to the console, I see nothing out of the ordinary either. I can even download and base64 the `File` and open it in an external service without any issues.\r\n\r\nIt seems to me that the `File` is, in fact, a valid `File`. The code is hosted on a private repo which I'm not allowed to share. After compressing the image, it's sent directly using the `mutate` prop passed by the GraphQL HoC, no further adjustments are made to it.\r\n\r\n### Question\r\nI'm not very familiar with the apollo-upload-client, but if someone could give me some pointers in how I can further debug this myself, I'd be glad to do so!                               "title": "Jest v27 requires syntax that docs state is not needed for `reset()` method.",
                              "description": "This is a request to update the documentation for the [fetchMock.reset() method](https://www.wheresrhys.co.uk/fetch-mock/#api-lifecyclerestore_reset).\r\n\r\nAfter updating to Jest v.27.0.5 I had test suites failing with:\r\n```\r\nTest functions cannot both take a 'done' callback and return something. Either use a 'done' callback, or return a promise.\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe code that was failing was adhering to what is currently listed in the docs: `afterEach(fetchMock.reset);`.\r\nThe fix was to use syntax that is explicitly stated as not needed: `afterEach(() => fetchMock.reset());`\r\n\r\nWould appreciate a small fix to [current documentation ](https://www.wheresrhys.co.uk/fetch-mock/#api-lifecyclerestore_reset)that notes this actually may be needed in some circumstances.",

                         {
                              "title": "Sticky routes",
                              "description": "A test suite may need to always do something with a particular route e.g. provide a fixture instead of a request for config. This route can be defined in a `beforeEach` but\r\n- that feels a little inelegant and expensive\r\n- can force the user into importing stuff within describe/beforeEach blocks in order to avoid kicking off a request before the route has been set up\r\n\r\nIt would be nice to provide a way to mock something [semi-]permanently, that is resilient to calls to restore()/reset() etc\r\n\r\nAPI ideas:\r\n\r\n- Additional option 'sticky: true'\r\n- Shorthand `.sticky()`\r\n- Shorthands `.stickyPost()` ....\r\n- `reset({sticky: true})` affects even sticky routes",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2020-05-08T13:07:03Z",
                              "closedAt": "2020-05-11T20:45:04Z",

                              "commentCount": 0

                         {
                              "title": "fetchMock.get(string, \"\") fails due to \"fetch-mock: Invalid parameters passed to fetch-mock\"",
                              "description": "`fetchMock.get` fails due to `fetch-mock: Invalid parameters passed to fetch-mock` if the url parameter is a string and the response argument is `\"\"`. Non-empty strings work as expected. Example:\r\n\r\n```\r\nimport fetchMock from \"fetch-mock\";\r\n\r\nafterEach(() => {\r\n  fetchMock.reset();\r\n});\r\n\r\ndescribe('fetchMock', () => {\r\n\r\n  it('allows returning empty response', () => {\r\n    fetchMock.get(\"http://bla.blu\", \"\");\r\n  })\r\n})\r\n```\r\n\r\nI suspect this to be a bug because the response parameter can be a string and an empty response is valid for HTTP requests. Furthermore non-empty string are returned as response as expected.\r\n\r\nThe only related issue I found is #184 which is about improving the error message. It's fine afaik, I wouldn't mind more information which types are expected, though, but that's a separate concern, and since types are provided, it's not necessary.\r\n\r\nA complete example project is provided at https://gitlab.com/krichter-sscce/fetch-mock-empty-string-invalid-parameter. The behaviour can be triggered by running `yarn test` in the source root.\r\n\r\nVersion information from `yarn.lock`:\r\n\r\n```\r\nfetch-mock@^7.5.1:\r\n  version \"7.7.3\"\r\n  resolved \"https://registry.yarnpkg.com/fetch-mock/-/fetch-mock-7.7.3.tgz#6a3f94cfed6e423ab7f5464912982030da605335\"\r\n  integrity sha512-I4OkK90JFQnjH8/n3HDtWxH/I6D1wrxoAM2ri+nb444jpuH3RTcgvXx2el+G20KO873W727/66T7QhOvFxNHPg==\r\n  dependencies:\r\n    babel-polyfill \"^6.26.0\"\r\n    core-js \"^2.6.9\"\r\n    glob-to-regexp \"^0.4.0\"\r\n    lodash.isequal \"^4.5.0\"\r\n    path-to-regexp \"^2.2.1\"\r\n    whatwg-url \"^6.5.0\"\r\n```",

                              "createdAt": "2020-03-21T16:29:32Z",
                              "closedAt": "2020-03-21T18:51:30Z",
                              "lastComment": "2020-03-21T18:52:08Z",

response.text()) || \"{}\";\r\n  const json = JSON.parse(text);\r\n  if (response.ok) {\r\n    return Promise.resolve(json);\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  switch (json.errorCode) {\r\n    case }\r\n};\r\n\r\nexport const get = (url) => {\r\n  const options = {\r\n    method: 'GET',\r\n    credentials: 'same-origin'\r\n  };\r\n\r\n  return fetch(url,                               "title": "Repeated usage of mock fetch with delay",
                              "description": "Hi,\r\n\r\nI just started using your library and I ran into an issue when testing a function where I repeatedly use fetch until success. The `fetchTimeout` function aborts attempts to fetch after a preset period. In this example I abort after 10ms for purposes of demonstration.\r\n\r\n```js\r\nasync function fetchTimeout(url, options) {\r\n  // Abort a request after 10ms\r\n  const controller = new AbortController();\r\n  const timeout = setTimeout(() => { controller.abort() }, 10);\r\n  const optionsSignal = {\r\n    ...options,\r\n    signal: controller.signal\r\n  };\r\n\r\n  try {\r\n    return await fetch(url, optionsSignal);\r\n  } finally {\r\n    clearTimeout(timeout);\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nI call the above `fetchTimeout` function until I get a satisfactory response or a limit is reached. Between each call to fetchTimeout I back off for 500ms. With the below setup, I was expecting for the fetch to never succeed because the 5000ms delay I configured for fetch, should always be longer than the 10ms fetch is given until it aborts. In my real code, all of the retry logic (which is more robust and complicated than below) is of course in my source code, not in my test code, but I thought this would be helpful to demonstrate.\r\n\r\n```js\r\n      const mockFetch = fetchMock.sandbox().get(\r\n        'http://foo.bar.com',\r\n        200,\r\n        {\r\n          delay: 5000\r\n        }\r\n      );\r\n\r\n      sinon.replace(fetch, 'default', mockFetch);\r\n\r\n      for (let i = 0; i<100; i++) {\r\n        console.log(`Run ${i}`);\r\n        try {\r\n          const res = await fetchTimeout('http://foo.bar.com', {});\r\n          if (res.ok) {\r\n            console.log('Breaking out!');\r\n            break;\r\n          }\r\n        } catch(err) {\r\n          // Swallow AbortErrors only\r\n          if (err.name !== 'AbortError') {\r\n            throw(err);\r\n          }\r\n        }\r\n        // Delay for 500ms\r\n        await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 500));\r\n      }\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt looks like the 5000ms `delay` is somehow not per call to fetch however. After a few iterations (roughly 10, which fits with the 500ms backoff), the for loop will abort because fetch succeeeded.\r\n\r\nIs this intended? I would have thought that the delay should be per call to fetch.",

                              "title": "fetch(new Request()) throws a TypeError fetch-mock: Unrecognised Request object",
                              "description": "I am using fetch-mock 7.3.3 with @types/fetch-mock 7.3.1 (not sure why these versions are different) and I was getting an error similar to the one raised in this closed issue https://github.com/wheresrhys/fetch-mock/issues/156\r\n\r\nReading that other thread, I was able to fix it by modifying the proposed solution that wraps the fetchHandler. \r\n\r\n```\r\nconst fetchMock = require('fetch-mock');\r\n\r\nconst _fetchMock = fetchMock.fetchHandler;\r\nfetchMock.fetchHandler = (url, options) => {\r\n  if (url instanceof Request && options === undefined) {\r\n    // Function was called with a single argument of type Request\r\n    return _fetchMock(url.url, { method: url.method });\r\n  }\r\n  return _fetchMock(url, options);\r\n};\r\n```\r\n\r\nI am using TypeScript with Node and Jest\r\n\r\n",

                              "title": "Requests that pass an URL object to fetch do not get matched",
                              "description": "When wanting to perform a GET request that includes query parameters the [fetch standard recommends](https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#fetch-api) constructing a `new window.URL`, appending to its `searchParams` and then directly passing this URL object to `fetch`. From the doc:\r\n\r\n```js\r\nvar url = new URL(\"https://geo.example.org/api\"),\r\n    params = {lat:35.696233, long:139.570431}\r\nObject.keys(params).forEach(key => url.searchParams.append(key, params[key]))\r\nfetch(url).then(/* … */)\r\n```\r\n\r\nI tried using `fetch-mock` to mock this kind of request, but found that it would not match the request until I explicitly called `.toString()` on the URL object. Passing an URL object to the matcher would not work either.\r\n\r\nI.e. I have code like:\r\n\r\n```js\r\nexports.fetchURL = (url) => {\r\n\tconst u = new URL(url);\r\n\treturn fetch(u).then(res => res.json());\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nthat will be tested llike this:\r\n\r\n```js\r\ndescribe('fetchURL', () => {\r\n\tcontext('with string matcher', () => {\r\n\t\tbefore(() => {\r\n\t\t\tfetchMock.get('http://api.example.com/resource/123', { ok: true });\r\n\t\t});\r\n\t\tafter(() => {\r\n\t\t\tfetchMock.restore();\r\n\t\t\tfetchMock.reset();\r\n\t\t});\r\n\t\t// fails with Error: No fallback response defined for GET to http://api.example.com/resource/123\r\n\t\tit('resolves with the payload', () => {\r\n\t\t\treturn fetchURL('http://api.example.com/resource/123').then((payload) => {\r\n\t\t\t\tassert.deepStrictEqual(payload, { ok: true });\r\n\t\t\t});\r\n\t\t});\r\n\t});\r\n\r\n\tcontext('with URL matcher', () => {\r\n\t\tbefore(() => {\r\n\t\t\tfetchMock.get(new URL('http://api.example.com/resource/123'), { ok: true });\r\n\t\t});\r\n\t\tafter(() => {\r\n\t\t\tfetchMock.restore();\r\n\t\t\tfetchMock.reset();\r\n\t\t});\r\n\t\t// fails with TypeError: route.matcher.indexOf is not a function\r\n\t\tit('resolves with the payload', () => {\r\n\t\t\treturn fetchURL('http://api.example.com/resource/123').then((payload) => {\r\n\t\t\t\tassert.deepStrictEqual(payload, { ok: true });\r\n\t\t\t});\r\n\t\t});\r\n\t});\r\n});\r\n```\r\n\r\nbut both tests fail. The actual URL may have additional query parameters, they will be ignored.\r\n\r\n```js\r\nconst matchUrl = expectedUrlStr => actualUrlStr => {\r\n  const parseOne = u => url.parse(u, true);\r\n\r\n  const expectedUrl = parseOne(expectedUrlStr);\r\n  const actualUrl = parseOne(actualUrlStr);\r\n\r\n  if (expectedUrl.pathname !== actualUrl.pathname) {\r\n    return false;\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  for (const key in expectedUrl.query) {\r\n    if (expectedUrl.query[key] !== actualUrl.query[key]) {\r\n      return false;\r\n    }\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  return true;\r\n};\r\n```\r\n\r\n</details>\r\n",

                              "title": "Returning Promise in older browsers",

I guess some Babel or webpack vodoo is going on there :x\n\nUpdate 2: I could fix this by removing the babel-runtime plugin from my webpack config. Still not sure what is really causing this...\n\nUpdate 3: Okay I think I understand this now: `babel-plugin-transform-runtime` replaces every call to built in ES6 types (like Promise) with a reference to the babel-core polyfill, so it does NOT polyfill the globals. Since babel should not convert node_modules/ it cannot convert the Promise inside of fetchMock, so that this Promise and babel promise don't share the same identity.\n",

                         {
                              "title": "v5 proposals",
                              "description": "## Handling unmatched requests\n\nCurrently configured by passing `greed: 'good'|'bad'|false` in to `mock()`. Inadvertently, this persists even after `restore()` is called, which is a bug, but not necessarily worse behaviour than intended. What might be better is either \n- a global config option, documented as such\n- better warnings and errors, documentation pointing users towards putting lots of catch-all mocks in a beforeEach, and deprecating the `greed` option. Less magic, smaller API.\n  - perhaps accept a `'*'` matcher, or maybe a `.catch()` method to define how unmatched calls are handled\n## Global config\n\nSetting things such as\n- How much processing to apply to the mock response (e.g. `sendAsJson`)\n## Accept a `Response` object as the response\n\nCould also be worth exposing the response creator as a utility\n## Major API change\n\nHaving `method` as an optional second parameter makes modifying the API trickier\n\n.the API could change to `mock(matcher, response, options)`, with shorthands of `get()`, `post()` etc. `mockOnce()`, `getOnce()` etc would also be nice (see below)\n## Other things to consider\n- Configure number of times a response can be matched - see https://github.com/wheresrhys/fetch-mock/compare/times for failing tests\n- Possibly change/augment the behaviour of call matching https://github.com/wheresrhys/fetch-mock/pull/83\n- remove reMock. restore/reset should return instance of fetch-mock so they are chainable\n- accept an array of arrays to a single call of fetchMock?? (not so useful now is chainable `.mock(a, b).mock(c,d)` vs `.mock([[a,b], [c,d]])`)... deprecate mocking arrays???\n",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2016-06-06T21:16:30Z",
                              "closedAt": "2016-07-13T20:55:42Z",
                              "lastComment": "2016-07-13T20:55:42Z",
                              "commentCount": 4
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "Add support (fix bug) for  functions returning a Promise",
                              "description": "I tried to mock server delays and  I needed a Promise to be created at a time when a request is made to a mocked url, not at a time when we define how to mock a response.\nThe current implementation does not currently handle a case when the response is mocked as  a function returning a Promise. To fix it for my needs I added one line to fetchMock function, like this:\n\n```\nfetchMock (url, opts) {\n    const response = this.router(url, opts);\n    if (typeof response === 'function')  response = response(url, opts);  // <-- the new line\n```\n\nIt moves evaluating the \"mocking function\" from mockResponse to fetchMock because fetchMock has proper logic (using \"response.then\") for Promises. \n",

                         {
                              "title": "Not matching when fetch is called with a Request object",
                              "description": "The `normalizeRequest()` function in fetch-mock.js is supposed to check if it is called with a URL string or a Request object.  This is failing, and falling back to the string case when fetch() is invoked with a Request object.\n\nHere's an example:\n\n```\nlet req = new Request('http://www.example.com', { method: 'GET' });\nlet p = fetch(req);\n```\n\nThe following implementation works for me, but may be too simplistic of a fix:\n\n```\nfunction normalizeRequest (url, options) {\n    if (typeof url === 'string') {\n        return {\n            url: url,\n            method: options && options.method || 'GET'\n        };\n    } else {\n        return {\n            url: url.url,\n            method: url.method\n        };\n    }\n}\n```\n",

                              "title": "FetchMock.getMock seems always undefined as of 4.0.0",
                              "description": "I am using FetchMock with Mockery as Node 4 module, hence I need to get a handle on the mocked fetch() function.\n\nRegistering the node-fetch mock with `myMock.getMock()` as shown below leads to an undefined fetch function in the code under test.\n\n```\n'use strict';\n\nvar fetchMock = require('fetch-mock');\nvar mockery = require('mockery');\n\ndescribe('fetch mockery', function () {\n\n  beforeEach(function () {\n    mockery.enable({useCleanCache: true});\n    var myMock = fetchMock\n      .mock('http://auth.service.com/user', '{\"foo\": 1}');\n    mockery.registerMock('node-fetch', myMock.getMock());        <-- undefined\n  });\n\n  afterEach(function () {\n    fetchMock.restore();\n    mockery.deregisterMock('node-fetch');\n    mockery.disable();\n  });\n\n  it('should mock a request', function () {\n\n    var goFetch = require('../lib/fetchsample'); // just a call to fetch in a separate module\n\n    return goFetch('http://auth.service.com/user').then(function (response) {\n      return response.json();\n    }).then(function (json) {\n      console.log(json);\n    });\n  });\n\n});\n\n```\n\nAs a workaround, the necessary fetch function mock is availabe as `myMock.mockedContext.fetch`:\n\n```\nmockery.registerMock('node-fetch', myMock.mockedContext.fetch);\n```\n\nMaybe the fix would be to change `getMock()` in fetch-mock.js like so:\n\n```\n    /**\n     * getMock\n     * Returns a reference to the stub function used to mock fetch\n     * @return {Function}\n     */\n    getMock () {\n        return this.mockedContext.fetch;\n    }\n```\n\nOr am I using fetch-mock incorrectly here?\n",

                         {
                              "title": "Cannot mock relative URLs in v3.0.4",
                              "description": "As of v3.0.4, mocking a relative URL results in an `Error` being thrown from the dependency module [`node-fetch`](https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch):\n\n```\nError: only absolute urls are supported\n    at new Request (node_modules/fetch-mock/node_modules/node-fetch/lib/request.js:34:9)\n    at toRequest (node_modules/fetch-mock/src/fetch-mock.js:65:13)\n    at Object.route.matcher (node_modules/fetch-mock/src/fetch-mock.js:111:15)\n    at node_modules/fetch-mock/src/fetch-mock.js:233:15\n    at Array.some (native)\n    at routes.forEach.routes.forEach.routes.some (node_modules/fetch-mock/src/fetch-mock.js:231:11)\n    at mock (node_modules/fetch-mock/src/fetch-mock.js:329:21)\n    ....\n```\n\nIn my use case, I am writing tests for a Redux application which uses `fetch` to grab some i18n data defined in a JSON file.   The code I am testing looks like this:\n\n``` javascript\nfetch(`public/i18n/${locale}.json`)\n  .then(/* ...snip... */)\n```\n\nThe tests are written in [`mocha`](https://mochajs.org/) and are executed through Node.js, so I use [`isomorphic-fetch`](https://github.com/matthew-andrews/isomorphic-fetch) assigned to the `global` object inside the test, to fill in for the browser's `fetch` function, and use `fetch-mock` to mock the response:\n\n``` javascript\nimport fetchMock from 'fetch-mock'\nimport fetch from 'isomorphic-fetch'\n\nglobal.fetch = fetch\n/* ...snip... */\nfetchMock.mock(`public/i18n/${locale}.json`, { /* fixture i18n data */ })\n```\n\nThis code worked fine in v3.0.3 as `fetch-mock` wasn't using `Request` from `node-fetch`, which sets the absolute URL limitation ([LIMITS.md in `node-fetch` repository](https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/blob/master/LIMITS.md)).\n\nRelated issue in `node-fetch`: https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/issues/43\n",

                              "title": "Feature request - lazy load",
                              "description": "I expected the computed getter to only fire when the getter is accessed. Do you think it's implementable as an option? `{ lazy: true }`\r\n\r\nI was able to implement the behaviour, but had to change a lot:\r\n```js\r\nconst prefix = 'async_computed$'\r\n\r\nconst AsyncComputed = {\r\n  install (Vue, options) {\r\n    options = options || {}\r\n\r\n    Vue.config\r\n      .optionMergeStrategies\r\n      .asyncComputed = Vue.config.optionMergeStrategies.computed\r\n\r\n    Vue.mixin({\r\n      data () {\r\n        if (this.$options.asyncComputed) {\r\n          return {\r\n            async_computed$: {}\r\n          }\r\n        }\r\n        return {}\r\n      },\r\n      beforeCreate () {\r\n        if (!this.$options.asyncComputed) {\r\n          return\r\n        }\r\n\r\n        const optionComputed = this.$options.computed\r\n\r\n        if (!this.$options.computed) this.$options.computed = {}\r\n\r\n        const computed = (\r\n            (typeof optionComputed === 'function')\r\n              ? optionComputed.call(this)\r\n              : optionComputed\r\n           ) || {}\r\n\r\n        // Add computed getter for each key\r\n        Object.keys(this.$options.asyncComputed || {}).forEach(key => {\r\n          computed[key] = function () {\r\n            if (typeof this.$options.asyncComputed[key] !== 'function') {\r\n              return this.$options.asyncComputed[key]\r\n            }\r\n\r\n            if (!this['_request$' + prefix + key]) {\r\n              this['_request$' + prefix + key] = true\r\n\r\n              // Call computed property\r\n              this.$options.asyncComputed[key]()\r\n                .then(value => {\r\n\r\n                  // This will trigger watchers of the computed property\r\n                  // because a default value was set in $data\r\n                  this[prefix][key] = value\r\n\r\n                  // Hacky way of allowing to trigger again\r\n                  // Should use throttle-like function instead\r\n                  setTimeout(() => {\r\n                    this['_request$' + prefix + key] = true\r\n                  }, 25)\r\n                })\r\n                .catch(err => {\r\n\r\n                  // Error handler\r\n                  const handler = (options.errorHandler === undefined)\r\n                    ? console.error.bind(console, 'Error evaluating async computed property:')\r\n                    : options.errorHandler\r\n\r\n                  if (options.useRawError) {\r\n                    handler(err)\r\n                  } else {\r\n                    handler(err.stack)\r\n                  }\r\n                })\r\n            }\r\n\r\n            // Return computed value\r\n            return this[prefix][key]\r\n          }\r\n        })\r\n        this.$options.computed = computed\r\n      },\r\n      created () {\r\n        if (this.$options.asyncComputed) {\r\n\r\n          // Set default value\r\n          Object.keys(this.$options.asyncComputed || {}).forEach(key => {\r\n            const fn = this.$options.asyncComputed[key], def = typeof fn.default === 'undefined' ? null : fn.default\r\n            this.$set(this[prefix], key, typeof def === 'function' ? def.call(this) : def)\r\n          })\r\n        }\r\n      }\r\n    })\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n\r\nexport default AsyncComputed\r\n\r\n// Auto install in dist mode\r\nif (typeof window !== 'undefined' && window.Vue) {\r\n  window.Vue.use(AsyncComputed)\r\n}\r\n```",

                              "description": "You probably are aware of this issue, but I would like to point it out and ask you if you plan to release fix for this one:\r\n\r\nwhen you build your project with -p flag, webpack removes \" from scripts, so this \r\n\r\n`<script src=\"some_script.src\"></script>`\r\n\r\nwill become this \r\n\r\n`<script src=some_script.src></script>`\r\n\r\nand then your regexps won't work. \r\n\r\nFurthermore, it would be nice if plugin could just ignore <script> tags without src attributes - there are some cases that you would use this and fill in a dynamical manner, i.e.\r\n\r\n`<script id=\"this_will_be_filled\"></script>`\r\n\r\nPlease provide me with information if you plan to fix those, so I could use your awesome plugin and not have to build my own!                          {
                              "title": "proxymise not working with Knex queries",
                              "description": "proxymise is great, thank you!  \r\n\r\nUnfortunately I've just discovered that it's not working with Knex.js queries.  Here's an example which demonstrates the problem.\r\n\r\n```js\r\n// $ npm install knex sqlite3 proxymise\r\nimport Knex from 'knex'\r\nimport proxymise from 'proxymise';\r\n\r\nasync function main() {\r\n  // create Knex connection\r\n  const knex = Knex({\r\n    client: 'sqlite3',\r\n    useNullAsDefault: true,\r\n    connection: {\r\n      filename: ':memory:',\r\n    },\r\n  });\r\n\r\n  // create a users table\r\n  await knex.raw(\r\n    'CREATE TABLE users ( ' +\r\n    '  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY ASC, ' +\r\n    '  name TEXT ' +\r\n    ')'\r\n  );\r\n\r\n  // insert a row\r\n  await knex('users').insert({\r\n    name: 'kozhevnikov'\r\n  });\r\n\r\n  // knex example without proxymise()\r\n  const row = await knex('users').select('id', 'name').where({ name: 'kozhevnikov' }).first();\r\n  const name = row.name;\r\n  console.log('EXPECT name: ', name);\r\n\r\n  // works if knex method are inside proxymise()\r\n  try {\r\n    const prxm1 = proxymise(\r\n      knex('users')\r\n        .select('id', 'name')\r\n        .where({ name: 'kozhevnikov' })\r\n        .first()\r\n    );\r\n    const name1 = await prxm1.name;\r\n    console.log('PASSED name1:', name1);\r\n  }\r\n  catch(error) {\r\n    console.log('FAILED name1:', error);\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  // doesn't work when knex methods are outside proxymise()\r\n  try {\r\n    const prxm2 = proxymise(\r\n      knex('users')\r\n    );\r\n    const name2 = await prxm2\r\n      .select('id', 'name')\r\n      .where({ name: 'kozhevnikov' })\r\n      .first()\r\n      .name;\r\n    console.log('PASSED name2:', name2);\r\n  }\r\n  catch(error) {\r\n    console.log('FAILED name2:', error);\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  knex.destroy();\r\n}\r\n\r\nmain();\r\n```\r\n\r\nOutput:\r\n\r\n```sh\r\nEXPECT name:  kozhevnikov\r\nPASSED name1: kozhevnikov\r\nFAILED name2: TypeError: Function.prototype.apply was called on undefined, which is a undefined and not a function\r\n    at .../proxymise@1.0.2/node_modules/proxymise/index.js:27:53\r\n    at async main (file:///.../proxymise-knex-bug.js:53:19)",

               "issues": {
                    "incomplete_results": false,
                    "status_code": "200",
                    "total_bug_issues": 1,
                    "total_issues": 5,
                    "issues": [
                         {
                              "title": "[docs] how about for..of loop for sequential processing?",
                              "description": "Hi @getify,\r\n\r\nWanted to comment on a part of the readme below:\r\n\r\n> Unfortunately, aside from being more verbose, this \"fix\" is fairly limited. It really only works for map(..) and not for something like filter(..). Also, since it assumes concurrency, there's no way to do the iterations serially (for any of various reasons).\r\n\r\nalthough _assumes concurrency_ is true for `async function`s inside of `Promise.all`, you still have `for..of` loop available which would perfectly suit iterating over `users` (let it be array or any other iterable) that, given you `await` inside the loop, make it native sequential processing.\r\n\r\nSo I'm not sure if _there's no way to do the iterations serially_. Sure it fits `map` only - doesn't fit `filter`, `reduce` - but it's worth mentioning. IMHO it's the easiest approach for sequential processing within async functions, if you just `map` items sequentially.\r\n\r\nAnyway, good work, as always! :)",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2017-10-18T13:54:51Z",
                              "closedAt": "2017-10-19T00:40:22Z",
                              "lastComment": "2017-10-19T00:40:19Z",
                              "commentCount": 4
                         }

I am using jquery.soap.js version 1.6.7 and jquery version 1.11.3.\n\nFirst of all, here is my `$.soap` call.\n\n``` javascript\n$.soap({\n    url: 'myurl',\n    data: mydata,\n    appendMethodToUrl: false,\n    enableLogging: true,\n    soap12: true,\n    ...\n\n    success: function(SOAPResponse) {\n        console.log(\"success\");\n        console.log(SOAPResponse);\n    },\n    error: function(SOAPResponse) {\n        console.log(\"error\");\n        console.log(SOAPResponse);\n    }\n});\n```\n\nThe corresponding raw HTTP request:\n\n``` xml\nPOST /webservice/api?wsdl HTTP/1.1\nHost: localhost:8443\nConnection: keep-alive\nContent-Length: 503\nAccept: application/xml, text/xml, */*; q=0.01\nOrigin: http://localhost:63342\nUser-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Ubuntu Chromium/45.0.2454.101 Chrome/45.0.2454.101 Safari/537.36\nContent-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=UTF-8\nDNT: 1\nAccept-Encoding: gzip, deflate\nAccept-Language: de-DE,de;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4\n\n<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-8\"?>\n<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap=\"http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope\" xmlns:xsi=\"http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance\" xmlns:xsd=\"http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema\">\n    <soap:Body>\n        <tns:login xmlns:tns=\"mynamespace\">\n            <data>data</data>\n        </tns:login>\n    </soap:Body>\n</soap:Envelope>\n```\n\nAnd this is the response:\n\n``` xml\nHTTP/1.1 200 OK\nServer: Apache-Coyote/1.1\nAccess-Control-Allow-Origin: *\nAccess-Control-Allow-Methods: GET, POST\nContent-Type: multipart/related; type=\"application/xop+xml\"; boundary=\"uuid:4d5034cf-be88-457f-a80f-ad0300ea276d\"; start=\"<root.message@cxf.apache.org>\"; start-info=\"application/soap+xml\"\nContent-Length: 520\nDate: Wed, 25 Nov 2015 16:46:34 GMT\n\n--uuid:4d5034cf-be88-457f-a80f-ad0300ea276d\nContent-Type: application/xop+xml; charset=UTF-8; type=\"application/soap+xml\"\nContent-Transfer-Encoding: binary\nContent-ID: <root.message@cxf.apache.org>\n\n<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap=\"http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope\"><soap:Body><ns2:loginResponse xmlns:ns2=\"mynamespace\"><data>2e727q37-4048-4275-b7e2-e1f896c46eb3</data></ns2:loginResponse></soap:Body></soap:Envelope>\n--uuid:4d5034cf-be88-457f-a80f-ad0300ea276d--\n```\n\nSo the problem is that the `<soap:Envelope>` ist wrapped inside a multipart message. This results in a `parseerror` and the `error` callback is invoked. Is there anything I am missing? Or is it simply not possible to read multipart messages? Unfortunately this is something I cannot fix on the server side.\n\nAn acceptable workaround could be to extract the envelope by hand, e.g. with a regex. Is there a possibility to manipulate the response before the `error` callback is invoked?\nAny help is appreciated. Thanks!\n",

                         {
                              "title": "JSON: string objects VS string primitive",
                              "description": "In json2soap, String objects (built with \"new String('...')\") are processed as normal objects and produce an invalid XML file.\n\nIn demo, try \"{ test: new String('some text here...') }\" in params.\nYou will get the following error:\n\n```\nUncaught Error: Invalid XML: <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap=\"http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/\"><soap:Body><myns:helloWorld xmlns:myns=\"urn://service.my.server.com\"><myns:test><myns:0>s</myns:0><myns:1>o</myns:1><myns:2>m</myns:2><myns:3>e</myns...\n```\n\nTo fix this, I have added a new \"if\" in json2soap() function, to detect object strings and processed them as a primitive value.\nHere is the unified diff of the function:\n\n```\n                json2soap: function (name, params, prefix, parentNode) {\n                        var soapObject;\n                        var childObject;\n                        if (params === null) {\n                                soapObject = new SOAPObject(prefix+name);\n                                soapObject.attr('nil', true);\n                        } else if (typeof params == 'object') {\n                                // soapObject = new SOAPObject(prefix+name);\n                                // added by DT - check if object is in fact an Array and treat accordingly\n                                if(params.constructor.toString().indexOf(\"Array\") > -1) { // type is array\n                                        // soapObject = parentNode;\n                                        for(var x in params) {\n                                                childObject = this.json2soap(name, params[x], prefix, parentNode);\n                                                parentNode.appendChild(childObject);\n                                        }\n+                               } else if (params.constructor.toString().indexOf(\"String\") > -1) { // type is string\n+                                       // handle String objects as string primitive value\n+                                       soapObject = new SOAPObject(prefix+name);\n+                                       soapObject.val(''+params); // the ''+ is added to fix issues with falsey values.\n                                } else {\n                                        soapObject = new SOAPObject(prefix+name);\n                                        for(var y in params) {\n                                                childObject = this.json2soap(y, params[y], prefix, soapObject);\n                                                if (childObject) {\n                                                        soapObject.appendChild(childObject);\n                                                }\n                                        }\n                                }\n                        } else {\n                                soapObject = new SOAPObject(prefix+name);\n                                soapObject.val(''+params); // the ''+ is added to fix issues with falsey values.\n                        }\n                        return soapObject;\n                },\n```\n\nPS: I do not really use new String() to create a string, but I am defining new methods in String.prototype, and when using these added methods my string are converted to Objects.\n",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2014-04-12T20:44:27Z",
                              "closedAt": "2014-04-16T07:44:21Z",
                              "lastComment": "2014-04-14T10:02:40Z",
                              "commentCount": 1
                         },

                              "description": "The global cache TTL takes precedence over the more specific function TTL when the function TTL is 0. As can be seen from the output, the function is called only once.\r\n\r\n```\r\n$ cat example.mjs\r\nimport { createCache } from 'async-cache-dedupe'\r\n\r\nconst cache = createCache({\r\n  ttl: 5,\r\n  storage: { type: 'memory' },\r\n})\r\n\r\ncache.define('fetchSomething', { ttl: 0 }, async (k) => {\r\n  console.log('query', k)\r\n  return { k }\r\n})\r\n\r\nawait cache.fetchSomething(1)\r\nawait cache.fetchSomething(1)\r\nawait cache.fetchSomething(1)\r\n```\r\n\r\n```\r\n$ node example.mjs \r\nquery 1\r\n```\r\n\r\nI've tested against version 1.2.2 of async-cache-dedupe.\r\n\r\n```\r\n$ cat package.json \r\n{\r\n  \"name\": \"zero-ttl\",\r\n  \"version\": \"1.0.0\",\r\n  \"dependencies\": {\r\n    \"async-cache-dedupe\": \"1.2.2\"\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n",

                              "title": "AwsV4Signer::sign invalid for S3 GET with signQuery",
                              "description": "When I use `aws s3 presign` like this,\r\n\r\n```\r\nAWS_REGION=ap-northeast-1 \\\r\nAWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=AKIA................ \\\r\nAWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=........................................ \\\r\naws s3 presign 's3://BUCKET_NAME/BUCKET_KEY'\r\n```\r\n\r\nI get a URL like this, which works.\r\n\r\n```\r\nhttps://BUCKET_NAME.s3.ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com/BUCKET_KEY\r\n  ?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256\r\n  &X-Amz-Credential=AKIA................%2F20210608%2Fap-northeast-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request\r\n  &X-Amz-Date=20210608T051344Z\r\n  &X-Amz-Expires=3600\r\n  &X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host\r\n  &X-Amz-Signature=ccf8e91fc184c3805342093f0b68f111cfa04790f5e8b2ae7abd3511f05ff127\r\n```\r\n\r\nBut when I use AwsV4Signer::sign like this,\r\n\r\n```js\r\nlet url = 'https://BUCKET_NAME.s3.ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com/BUCKET_KEY'\r\nlet params = {url, accessKeyId, secretAccessKey, signQuery: true}\r\nlet signer = new AwsV4Signer(params)\r\nlet {url: {href}} = await signer.sign()\r\nconsole.log(href)\r\n```\r\n\r\nI get a URL like this, which does not work.\r\n\r\n```\r\nhttps://BUCKET_NAME.s3.ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com/BUCKET_KEY\r\n  ?X-Amz-Date=20210608T051604Z\r\n  &X-Amz-Expires=86400\r\n  &X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256\r\n  &X-Amz-Credential=AKIATTIKK53SN5ZYA7UX%2F20210608%2Fap-northeast-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request\r\n  &X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host%3Bx-amz-content-sha256\r\n  &X-Amz-Signature=bffa444c66d3f959a691b9d4886387c0a1b74809dd0658939128e5741cd16056\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt seems that aws4fetch is adding the `x-amz-content-sha256` to the signed headers (and omitting it from the querystring), which apparently is not correct for querystring signatures.\r\n\r\nI fixed this for my limited use case by adding `'x-amz-content-sha256'` to `UNSIGNABLE_HEADERS`, but I imagine this would break signing for non-querystring, non-GET cases.",

                              "title": "Installing via npm includes missing type definitions",
                              "description": "I just installed version 1.0.13 on NPM.                          {
                              "title": "`RegularTableElement.scrollTo` shadows base `HTMLElement.scrollTo` method",
                              "description": "I took a first stab at writing a typescript type declaration file ([regular-table.d.ts](https://github.com/telamonian/tree-finder/blob/master/src/regular_table.d.ts)). In the `RegularTableElement` class declaration, I had to leave out:\r\n\r\n```\r\nscrollTo(x: number, y: number, ncols: number, nrows: number): void;\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis is because the above is not compatible with the signature of the base method `HTMLElement.scrollTo`, as defined in typescript's standard `lib.dom.d.ts`:\r\n\r\n```\r\ninterface ScrollToOptions extends ScrollOptions {\r\n    left?: number;\r\n    top?: number;\r\n    behavior?: \"auto\" | \"smooth\";\r\n}\r\n\r\n...\r\n\r\n    scrollTo(options?: ScrollToOptions): void;\r\n    scrollTo(x: number, y: number): void;\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis is likely to be a pain point for anyone trying to consume regular-table in a typescript project (at the least, they won't be able to call `scrollTo` on a `RegularTableElement` instance without a cast).\r\n\r\nPotential fixes:\r\n\r\n- (easy) Change the name of `scrollTo`. For example, we could use `scrollToCell`\r\n- (more complex) Add explicit handling of `arguments` to `scrollTo`",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2020-06-15T10:22:45Z",
                              "closedAt": "2020-06-20T00:39:55Z",
                              "lastComment": "",
                              "commentCount": 0
                         },
                         {

                              "title": "Support for @seald-io/nedb@3.0.0 (and later)",
                              "description": "The current version of nedb-promises is affected by [CVE-2021-43138 ]( https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-fwr7-v2mv-hh25).\r\n\r\nthe dependency to async [was removed in version 3.0.0 of @seald-io/nedb ](https://github.com/seald/nedb/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#300---2022-03-16). \r\n\r\nAlso @seald-io/nedb has a Promise-based API beginning from 3.0.0. Unfortunately this new API is not compatible with the implementation of nedb-promises, as it adds the `Async` suffix to all the method names.\r\n\r\nFrom my point of view, a lot of code of this repository could be refactored to internally use the `Async` methods.\r\n\r\n**But more important would be to get rid of the security issue.**",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-04-13T13:29:27Z",

                         },
                         {
                              "title": "findOne gives type <T> but can be null",
                              "description": "### Problem:\r\nBasically, the `findOne` call assumes something is found whether or not it actually was, and TypeScript therefore doesn't alert you of trying to get properties from null.\r\n\r\n```js\r\nconst data = await db.findOne<{ name: string }>({ id: 1 });\r\nconsole.log(data.name); // No TypeScript warning, but throws a TypeError if no row has id = 1\r\n```\r\nThe returned type becomes `<T & Document>` but I think it should be `<(T & Document) | null>`. Alternatively throw some error.\r\n\r\n```js\r\nconst data = await db.findOne<{ name: string }>({ id: 1 });\r\nconsole.log(data.name); // TypeScript warning: Object is possibly 'null'\r\nif (data) {\r\n  console.log(data.name) // Safe\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis may also apply to some other similar methods.\r\n\r\nSide note: Giving it a type like `findOne<T | null>()` doesn't work either, it still becomes `T & Document`\r\n\r\n### Possible solution:\r\nChange the return type for `findOne` from `Promise<T & Document>` to `Promise<(T & Document) | null>`. This provides the desired effect, but I haven't delved into possible side effects and may be considered a breaking change for users who don't do this type check in their code already (although they are at risk of TypeErrors if not)",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-02-19T17:42:40Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-02-22T01:52:57Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-02-22T01:52:57Z",
                              "commentCount": 7
                         },

                              "title": "publish does not block or throw even if there is no Internet connection",
                              "description": "Hello,\r\n\r\nI've encountered an issue associated with the loss of internet connection during publishing data.\r\nEvent if there is no Internet connection, publish method does not throw or block - it simply acts, like the data was send successfully.\r\nIs this behavior intentional?\r\n\r\nIf so, is there a possibility to check whether publish was send to the server?\r\nI would like to store this data and send them after the return of Internet connection.\r\n\r\nBelow you will find my code for testing:\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nconst mqtt = require(\"async-mqtt\");\r\nconst credentials = require(\"./credentials.json\");\r\nconst connectionURL = \"presiot.mciotextension.eu1.mindsphere.io\";\r\n\r\nconst connectionOptions = {\r\n  port: 1883,\r\n  clientId: \"mqttjs_87654324\",\r\n  username: \"presiot/\" + credentials.username,\r\n  password: credentials.password,\r\n  device_name: \"mqttjs_87654324\",\r\n  tenant: \"presiot\",\r\n  protocol: \"mqtt/tcp\",\r\n  host: \"mciotextension.eu1.mindsphere.io\",\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst snooze = (ms) => new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(resolve, ms));\r\n\r\n/**\r\n * @description Method for generating command with random value\r\n */\r\nlet generateCommandWithRandValue = () => {\r\n  //Generating value and timestamp to send\r\n  let value = Math.round(Math.random() * 1000000) / 100;\r\n  let timestamp = Date.now();\r\n\r\n  return [\r\n    200,\r\n    \"variableGroup\",\r\n    \"variableName\",\r\n    value.toFixed(2),\r\n    \"V\",\r\n    new Date(timestamp).toISOString(),\r\n  ].join(\",\");\r\n};\r\n\r\nlet exec = async () => {\r\n  //Connecting\r\n  let client = await mqtt.connectAsync(connectionURL, connectionOptions);\r\n\r\n  while (true) {\r\n    try {\r\n      //Waiting 1s\r\n      await snooze(1000);\r\n\r\n      //Generating command to send\r\n      let command = generateCommandWithRandValue();\r\n\r\n      //BREAKING INTERNET CONNECTION HERE\r\n\r\n      //Sending value to mqtt broker\r\n      await client.publish(\"s/us\", command);\r\n\r\n      //EVEN IF THERE IS NO INTERNET PUBLISH DOES NOT THROW OR BLOCK - COMMAND IS TREATED AS SEND PROPERLY\r\n\r\n      console.log(`Command send properly: ${command}`);\r\n    } catch (err) {\r\n      console.log(err);\r\n    }\r\n  }\r\n};\r\n\r\nexec();\r\n",

\"last_revision_username\": \"apisrijanstuff\",\r\n      \"stuff_asset_id\": \"600007070\"\r\n    }\r\n  ],\r\n  \"meta\": {\r\n    \"count\": 1\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n```\r\nAs you can see it is getting overwritten by the first `meta` object value \r\n```\r\n\"meta\": {\r\n    \"value\": {\r\n      \"original\": \"https://platform-admin-stage-media.staging.nebula-drupal.stuff.co.nz/s3fs-public/2022-10/eSO6cM0L8_-Zy6fFR0GXNaBNUg0_1.jpg\",\r\n      \"crop_1_1\": {\r\n        \"width\": \"100\",\r\n        \"height\": \"100\",\r\n        \"x\": \"10\",\r\n        \"y\": \"10\"\r\n      }\r\n    },\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe expected output should be this\r\n\r\n```\r\n{\r\n  \"jsonapi\": {\r\n    \"version\": \"1.0\",\r\n    \"meta\": {\r\n      \"links\": {\r\n        \"self\": {\r\n          \"href\": \"http://jsonapi.org/format/1.0/\"\r\n        }\r\n      }\r\n    }\r\n  },\r\n  \"data\": [\r\n \"id\": \"6e0eca07-bc2e-4b2a-af42-7fc58138cb68\",\r\n            \"field_media_override\": {\r\n              \"data\": {\r\n                \"type\": \"media--image\",\r\n                \"id\": \"842b1824-2982-4fcb-8dc7-780c1ae71d81\",\r\n                \"thumbnail\": {\r\n                  \"data\": {\r\n                    \"id\": \"2025398c-0197-4728-800b-21e4b96644e7\",\r\n \"coronetpeak.jpeg\",\r\n                      \"title\": null,\r\n                      \"width\": 1340,\r\n                      \"height\": 876\r\n                    }\r\n                  }\r\n                },\r\n                \"meta\": {\r\n                  \"value\": {\r\n                    \"original\":                          {
                              "title": "Serialise any valid JSON in attributes",
                              "description": "Hello,\r\n\r\nThis is a *feature request*.\r\n\r\nCurrently, the serialiser attempts extract data that _should_ live in the relationships section and set the attributes to the remainder of the info (type, id). This prevents you from sending anything other than resources as attributes.\r\n\r\nIn the [JSONAPI spec for attributes](https://jsonapi.org/format/#document-resource-object-attributes) it says that\r\n> Attributes may contain any valid JSON value.\r\n\r\nIt would be great to conform to the spec and allow any information to be placed in the attributes.\r\n\r\n## Problems\r\nAs far as I can see, this doesn't present any major issues other than a redesign of some of the methods in the (de)serialiser. I might suggest that we, instead, check for the `type` attribute of any objects that appear and use that as the identifier for whether to extract to relationships or not. Would love to know if you have any better suggestions (you'll be able to guess the ramifications far better than I can!)",

                         {
                              "title": "GET/POST/PATCH/DELETE do not handle relationships in the model parameter",
                              "description": "Discovered thanks to an email by a user, which I'm surprised I didn't discover the mistake sooner.\r\n\r\n**Note:** _Examples below use `post` as the parent resource and `comment` as the relationship resource_\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n# GET\r\n\r\nRelated spec: https://jsonapi.org/format/#fetching-relationships\r\n\r\nGET has a different error compared to POST/PATCH/DELETE as it handles self relationship requests (get id/type/attributes/relationships) `post/1/comment`, but not related relationship requests (get id/type) as its implementation only uses the first 3 strings separated by `/`, making the request URI correct to `post/1` but the type is `relationships` instead of `comment`.\r\n\r\nPotential refactoring for this method would be to store the 4th item and check if the 4th item exists and the 3rd item is \"relationships\" to turn `api.fetch('post/1/relationships/comment')` into `GET https://example.api/posts/1/relationships/comments`.\r\n\r\n# POST\r\n\r\nRelated spec: https://jsonapi.org/format/#crud-updating-to-many-relationships\r\n\r\nCurrently with `api.create('post/1/comment', '...')` it will attempt to create a resource with the type `posts/1/comments`. Correct behaviour is per the spec:\r\n\r\n>In the following example, the comment with ID 123 is added to the list of comments for the article with ID 1:\r\n\r\n```\r\nPOST /articles/1/relationships/comments HTTP/1.1\r\nContent-Type: application/vnd.api+json\r\nAccept: application/vnd.api+json\r\n\r\n{\r\n  \"data\": [\r\n    { \"type\": \"comments\", \"id\": \"123\" }\r\n  ]\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\n# PATCH\r\n\r\nRelated spec: https://jsonapi.org/format/#crud-updating-to-one-relationships and https://jsonapi.org/format/#crud-updating-to-many-relationships\r\n\r\nSame as POST but can also remove relationships with `data: null` on one-to-one relationships and `data: []` on one-to-many relationships.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n# DELETE\r\n\r\nRelated spec: https://jsonapi.org/format/#crud-updating-to-many-relationships\r\n\r\nSame as POST, but deleting instead of adding relationships 😉\r\n\r\n>In the following example, comments with IDs of 12 and 13 are removed from the list of comments for the article with ID 1:\r\n\r\n```\r\nDELETE /articles/1/relationships/comments HTTP/1.1\r\nContent-Type: application/vnd.api+json\r\nAccept: application/vnd.api+json\r\n\r\n{\r\n  \"data\": [\r\n    { \"type\": \"comments\", \"id\": \"12\" },\r\n    { \"type\": \"comments\", \"id\": \"13\" }\r\n  ]\r\n}\r\n```",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2018-12-03T13:36:36Z",
                              "closedAt": "2020-05-07T10:01:40Z",
                              "lastComment": "2020-05-07T10:01:40Z",
                              "commentCount": 1
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "Fix \"argument_count\" issue in packages/kitsu-core/src/serialise/index.js",
                              "description": "Function `serialiseObject` has 5 arguments (exceeds 4 allowed). Consider refactoring.\n\nhttps://codeclimate.com/github/wopian/kitsu/packages/kitsu-core/src/serialise/index.js#issue_5b73904103ff7d000100003e",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2018-08-15T02:36:47Z",
                              "closedAt": "2018-08-15T02:36:52Z",
                              "lastComment": "",
                              "commentCount": 0
                         },

                         {
                              "title": "Can't use the same action type in more than one graph state",
                              "description": "Problem: Graphs that need multiple handlers for the same action type fail, e.g.:\r\n\r\n```js\r\nconst actionStates = ['initial', SIGNED_OUT,\r\n  ['sign in', AUTHENTICATING,\r\n    ['report sign in failure', ERROR,\r\n      ['handle sign in failure', SIGNED_OUT]\r\n    ],\r\n    ['report sign in success', SIGNED_IN,\r\n      ['sign out', SIGNED_OUT]\r\n    ]\r\n  ],\r\n  ['report sign in success', SIGNED_IN,\r\n    ['sign out', SIGNED_OUT]\r\n  ]\r\n];\r\n```\r\n\r\nIn this case, `reportSignInSuccess()` should be valid in multiple states, \"signed out\" or \"authenticating\". Currently, there can only be one handler per action type. The last one to be processed by the graph wins, causing the previous one to stop working.",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2018-01-19T21:58:28Z",
                              "closedAt": "2018-01-20T02:28:09Z",

                         {
                              "title": "Initial status is ignored.. 'idle' is always used.",
                              "description": "This graph:\r\n\r\n```js\r\nconst actionStates = [\r\n  ['initialize', 'signed out',\r\n    ['sign in', 'authenticating'\r\n      // ['report error', 'error',\r\n      //   ['handle error', 'signed out']\r\n      // ],\r\n      // ['sign-in success', 'signed in']\r\n    ]\r\n  ]\r\n];\r\n```\r\n\r\nshould initialize to the 'signed out' state. Instead, it initializes to idle:\r\n\r\n```\r\nnot ok 1 Given [\"initialize\", \"signed out\", /*...*/: should use \"signed out\" as initialized state\r\n  ---\r\n    operator: deepEqual\r\n    expected: |-\r\n      { status: 'signed out', payload: { type: 'empty' } }\r\n    actual: |-\r\n      { status: 'idle', payload: { type: 'empty' } }\r\n```\r\n\r\nI created a failing test that demonstrates the problem:\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/ericelliott/redux-dsm/blob/bug-initialState-ignored/source/test/authenticate-flow-test.js#L28\r\n  ",

                         {
                              "title": "Fix imports",
                              "description": "This is an ES6 module, meaning that you can't just import it in Node and start using it. You have to transpile or use `babel-core/register` prior to attempting to import it. Since this is a general-purpose library, I think the right approach is to switch to CommonJS module format, which AFAIK, is supported natively by Node, browserify, webpack, and JSPM, which I think covers all of the most common package managers in use today.\n\nTodo:\n- [ ] 1. `package.json` needs to point to `source/dsm.js` \n- [ ] 2. Swap out `import`/`export` with `require`/`module.exports`.  ([example](https://github.com/ericelliott/dpath/blob/a30d5a21cb51ca3a248453b9956be709a9a25c0b/source/index.js#L16)).\n- [ ] 3. No build step needed! Compiling for the intended targets is a job for the module users, not for us. We don't know the intended targets, so we don't know the right options to build for. If we give them the raw source, it gives users the flexibility and freedom they need to decide things like whether or not they need to bundle a generator runtime, etc...\n",

I ran an investigation and found that the MWS API is returning the data with a double newline towards the end, which is causing the issue.\r\n\r\nTo catch the issue, I downloaded the report as a txt file using the `amazon-mws` module with the following snippet in AmazonMwsResource.js:\r\n```javascript\r\n        function parseCSVFile(res, responseString, delimiter, callback) {\r\n            // Beginning of new code i added\r\n            const fs = require('fs');\r\n            fs.writeFile('/Users/jakeleventhal/Downloads/report.txt', responseString, (err) => {\r\n                if (err) throw err;\r\n            });\r\n            // End of new code i added\r\n            ...\r\n```\r\n\r\nI then created test.js that juse copies over the `parseCSVFile` from the AmazonMwsResource.js file so that I can try to correct the behavior:\r\n```javascript\r\nvar csv = require('fast-csv');\r\n\r\nfunction parseCSVFile(res, responseString, delimiter) {\r\n  var data = [];\r\n\r\n  var options = {\r\n    delimiter: delimiter,\r\n    headers: true,\r\n    discardUnmappedColumns: true,\r\n    quote: null,\r\n    ignoreEmpty: true,\r\n    trim: true\r\n  };\r\n\r\n  /* BAD CODE\r\n  if '');\r\n\r\n  csv.fromString(responseString, options)\r\n    .on('data', function (value) {\r\n      data.push(value);\r\n    })\r\n    .on('end', function () {\r\n      var items = {};\r\n      items.data = data;\r\n      console.log('bruh', items);\r\n      return items;\r\n    })\r\n    .on('error', function (error) {\r\n      debug('error ', error);\r\n      return error;\r\n    });\r\n}\r\n\r\nvar fs = require('fs');\r\nvar text = fs.readFileSync('/Users/jakeleventhal/Downloads/report.txt').toString();\r\n\r\nparseCSVFile(null, text, '\\t')\r\n```\r\n\r\nI replaced the \"BAD CODE\" with \"GOOD CODE\" and was able to get the result I am looking for.                          {
                              "message": "Fixed support for RadarRelay markets which didn't fit on the first page\n\nThe first thing the RadarRelay client used to do was querying the list\nof all markets (https://api.radarrelay.com/v2/markets) and looking for\nour market in it. This approach wasn't giving correct results as the\nmarkets list is paged, and most of markets do not fit on the first page\nwith the default `perPage=20`. Increasing `perPage` itself wasn't a\nsolution as the maximum value of this parameter in the RadarRelay API\nis `100`, but the total number of markets is greater than that.\n\nInstead of that I decided to query the individual market to verify its\nexistence. This way paging isn't an issue anymore.\n\nWith this fix, `WBTC-WETH` is now handled correctly.",

                         {
                              "title": "Chunked passthrough?",
                              "description": "A `WriteStream` created with `fs.createWriteStream()` accepts `a` flag, which allows the stream to be appended ([doc](https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v16.x/api/fs.html#file-system-flags)), via `Stream.pipe(writeStream, { end: false })`\r\nThis facilitates the so-called \"chunked uploads\", where a file that needs to be uploaded is first split at client's end\r\nEach chunks are then sent to the server, sequentially\r\nAnd server will then keep on piping each chunks to that single `WriteStream` as they come\r\n\r\nAssuming such workflow, I was wondering, does it make sense to request that one day `clamscan.passthrough()` be able to support such split/chunked data, somehow?\r\n\r\nI'd assume clamscan will have to facilitate withholding the passthrough data until they're done, before forwarding them to be scanned to clamav? Or somehow hold the stream until a code manually says that the stream has finished?\r\nHonestly the back-end of this all is a bit beyond me, and I only have some basic knowledge of how to make use of Streams and not their specifics, so excuse me if I'm not making much sense 😅 ",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-04-16T15:17:29Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-08-02T02:51:13Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-08-02T14:10:37Z",
                              "commentCount": 5
                         },
                         {

                              "title": "Init does not reject errors.",
                              "description": "We were trying to catch startup errors in the `init` method but not seeing them.  Thanks to our team member @saijian2008, we found the problem is index.js:571.  It should use `reject` not `resolve`, i.e.:\r\n```\r\nreturn (has_cb ? cb(err, false) : reject(err));\r\n```",

                         {
                              "title": "ember-fetch `input` type parameter is incorrect",
                              "description": "the generic `fetch` method's input parameter is typed as `URL | RequestInfo`, but ember-fetch only types it as `RequestInfo`. This causes issues when passing `fetch` as a function parameter in typescript, because ember-fetch is not assignable to regular ol' fetch.\r\n\r\nsee this TS playground for example: [playground link](https://www.typescriptlang.org/play?#code/JYWwDg9gTgLgBAUxAIwVAYgmBjAFnAMyghDgHIlUoBaArPMgbgChmCBXAO2xmAk7gwAhgGsEAZ0w5cAQXEAVAJ5gEACjrT0nAFyDlCCAUL1cASl0A3CMAAmcAN4BfVsLGSTcpSvUnTjOAD0AXAA5uzY2MDMrhJSeJ76qpRocWb+QXCcEPBhEcBAA)\r\n\r\nfix should be easy, just modify the types in `index.d.ts`, happy to make the PR",

                              "title": "Ember-Cli 3.5 + Ember-Fetch 6.1.0 + Monorepo Build Fails",
                              "description": "## Update & Solution\r\nBig thanks to @buschtoens in the Ember Discord - he quickly noted that this PR --> https://github.com/ember-cli/ember-fetch/pull/135 will solve this issue. \r\n\r\nUntil that merges, if you run into this issue, you can use this branch: `\"ember-fetch\": \"buschtoens/ember-fetch#upgrade\"`\r\n\r\n----\r\n\r\nWe are in the process of upgrading a large set of applications and addons to Ember 3.5. We are almost done with this project - we started with the addons, and are working on the applications, and we ran into this bug:\r\n\r\nEmber 3.5 + Ember Fetch > 5.2.1 + Monorepo: Build Fails with `Error: Couldn't find preset \"env\" relative to directory`\r\n\r\nWhen we force ember to use the broccoli 1 build (i.e. `EMBER_CLI_BROCCOLI_2=false ember b`), it works\r\n\r\n*Note:* Cross-posted as an issue in `ember-cli` as I'm not quite sure where the issue really lies\r\n\r\n## Repro Example\r\nI've created a repo with the repro scenario https://github.com/dbouwman/ember-fetch-monorepo-bug\r\n\r\n### Repro Steps (from README.md in the repo)\r\nWe suspect this is related to the use of Rollup within Ember-Fetch as the same error happens w Ember Fetch 5.1.2+ which is where the Rollup integration was added.\r\n\r\n## Repro Steps\r\n- create a monorepo using lerna + workspaces + yarn, add a package that is just a new ember 3.5 app, or just clone https://github.com/dbouwman/ember-fetch-monorepo-bug...\r\n- ensure you have `lerna` installed globally (`npm i -g lerna`)\r\n- ensure you have `yarn`\r\n- in the root, on `master`, run `yarn bootstrap` to install all the deps\r\n\r\n### State 1: No Ember-Fetch - Build is Fine...\r\n- `cd packages/ember-app`\r\n- `ember b` - this should succeed with the following:\r\n\r\n```\r\n➜  ember-app git:(master) ✗ ember b\r\nEnvironment: development\r\ncleaning up...\r\nBuilt project successfully. Stored in \"dist/\".\r\n```\r\n\r\n### State 2: Ember-Fetch ^6.1.0\r\n- either `ember install ember-fetch` or switch to the `ember-fetch-installed` branch and run `yarn bootstrap` in the root again.\r\n- run a build with `ember b`\r\n\r\nThis will fail with a message like:\r\n\r\n```\r\n➜  ember-app git:(ember-fetch-installed) ✗ ember b\r\nEnvironment: development\r\n(node:76156) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 1): Error: Couldn't find preset \"env\" relative to directory \"/var/folders/d8/rshjcmrd3_dcshnzs8f0hw7h0000gp/T/broccoli-76156VKmrFUG5tIdB/cache-037-rollup/build/src\"\r\n(node:76156) [DEP0018] DeprecationWarning: Unhandled promise rejections are deprecated. In the future, promise rejections that are not handled will terminate the Node.js process with a non-zero exit code.\r\n(node:76156) PromiseRejectionHandledWarning: Promise rejection was handled asynchronously (rejection id: 1)\r\ncleaning up...\r\nBuild Error (Rollup)\r\n\r\nCouldn't find preset \"env\" relative to directory \"/var/folders/d8/rshjcmrd3_dcshnzs8f0hw7h0000gp/T/broccoli-76156VKmrFUG5tIdB/cache-037-rollup/build/src\"\r\n\r\n\r\nStack Trace and Error Report: /var/folders/d8/rshjcmrd3_dcshnzs8f0hw7h0000gp/T/error.dump.a7d6df92295e51ce96d01a261577f0ce.log\r\n```\r\n\r\n[View the Stack Trace](https://github.com/dbouwman/ember-fetch-monorepo-bug/blob/master/stacktrace.md)\r\n\r\n### State 3: Use old Build Pipeline\r\n- with ember-fetch installed, run a build using the old build system - and it works.\r\n\r\n```\r\n➜  ember-app git:(ember-fetch-installed) ✗ EMBER_CLI_BROCCOLI_2=false ember b\r\nEnvironment: development\r\ncleaning up...\r\nBuilt project successfully. Stored in \"dist/\".\r\n```",

                              "title": "Not working with Fastboot and ember-data",
                              "description": "I've followed the documentation to add the initializer in `fastboot/initializer/ajax.js`\r\n\r\n```js\r\nexport default {\r\n  name: 'ajax-service',\r\n  initialize() {\r\n    // noop\r\n    // This is to override Fastboot's initializer which prevents ember-fetch from working\r\n    // https://github.com/ember-fastboot/ember-cli-fastboot/blob/master/fastboot/initializers/ajax.js\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nand adding the `AdapterFetch` mixin to my `adapters/application.js`\r\n\r\n```js\r\nimport DS from 'ember-data';\r\nimport AdapterFetch from 'ember-fetch/mixins/adapter-fetch';\r\n\r\nexport default DS.JSONAPIAdapter.extend(AdapterFetch, {\r\n});\r\n```\r\n\r\nBut am still getting an error message\r\n\r\n`TypeError: Only absolute URLs are supported`\r\n\r\nLooking into this error I've seen that there is already an issue relating to it\r\nhttps://github.com/ember-cli/ember-fetch/issues/110\r\n\r\nAnd also a PR which looks to address it\r\nhttps://github.com/ember-cli/ember-fetch/pull/128\r\n\r\nBut I cannot determine the correct path to resolving the issue.\r\n\r\nIn the comments of the issue there is a suggestion that this is fixed for `ember-data` but I don't see how to achieve this.\r\n\r\nThe PR seems out of date now due to so many subsequent commits so I tried to fork the `ember-fetch` repo and make the changes myself.\r\n\r\nSo I added `ember-fetch-adapter` as a dependency to the `package.json` and updating `addon/mixins/adapter-fetch.js` to use the adapter instead, by including the service in the mixin\r\n\r\n```js\r\n  adapter: service(),\r\n```\r\n\r\nand using the adapter service in the fetch request\r\n\r\n```\r\n  _fetchRequest(url, options) {\r\n    return this.adapter.fetch(url, options);\r\n  },\r\n```\r\n\r\nBut this now gives another error\r\n\r\n`Error: Assertion Failed: Attempting to inject an unknown injection: 'service:adapter'`\r\n\r\nI'm now at a loss as to how I can resolve this and to get `ember-fetch` working with `ember-data` and Fastboot.\r\n\r\nI'm open to any solution, is this absolute URL issue fixable yet?",

                         {
                              "title": "Typescript definitions don't work",
                              "description": "If you `import fetch from 'fetch'`, typescript won't resolve it. \r\nIf you `import fetch from 'ember-fetch'`, typescript _will_ resolve it, but you'll have a runtime error.\r\n\r\nWhen you import `fetch`, typescript looks in `node_modules/fetch`. It won't scan the whole `node_modules` directory for anyone exporting a `fetch` module. You can work around this with an explicit path mapping in `tsconfig.json`, but it's not conventional.\r\n\r\nMaybe this package could export `ember-fetch`, and eventually deprecate `fetch`?\r\n\r\n/cc @toranb @chriskrycho ",
                              "label": "bug",

                              "lastComment": "2019-03-12T06:45:43Z",
                              "commentCount": 18
