                         {
                              "title": "Fastboot dependency whitelisting",
                              "description": "Since Ember Fetch `1.4.2`, there appears to be an issue with using the `import fetch from 'fetch'` syntax in Fastboot apps, requiring a change to the fastboot dependency whitelist in package.json. \r\n\r\nThis issue relates to Ember Simple Auth, which has broken session restoration for Fastboot apps ever since upgrading to a later version of Ember Fetch. More details: https://github.com/simplabs/ember-simple-auth/issues/1138#issuecomment-319684132.\r\n\r\nThe fix appears to be to change `\"node-fetch\"` to just `\"fetch\"` in the app's `fastbootDependencies`. I'm just wondering whether that's an anticipated requirement for using Ember Fetch since defining `fetch` as a module import ([see here](https://github.com/ember-cli/ember-fetch/blob/994c0df4183185a812e0b096f79af3f26ed71937/public/fastboot-fetch.js#L2)) and whether it should be mentioned in the docs?",

                         {
                              "title": "Should this wrapper use native fetch, when available?",
                              "description": "I spent some time today writing some tests to expose what I thought was a bug here -- the polyfill is always used by `ember-fetch`; it will never fall back to native fetch, even when its available. \n\nI was sure this was a bug until I found https://github.com/pretenderjs/pretender/issues/60 with comments indicating that it was intended that this addon always uses the polyfill. \n\nIt's been almost a year since those comments, and Chrome and Firefox now appear to support fetch (http://caniuse.com/#search=fetch), should the native fetch be used, if available? Alternatively, a note in the Readme about why it always uses the polyfill would be great. \n\nIncidentally, I started down this path when someone told me they were using `ember-network` + `fetch` and were also using `ember-cli-mirage` for testing on a recent Chrome and I felt I had to solve the mystery of _how_ that worked. So, I have no real use case here and I certainly don't mind it using ajax. It does make testing easier that way, at least until pretender supports `fetch`.\n",

                         {
                              "title": "Listeners not removed",
                              "description": "Honestly, i have absolutely no idea what's going on. (iojs 1.8.1)\n\nA really simple `koa` app that demonstates the problem:\n\n``` js\n'use strict';\n\nrequire('async-listener');\nconst fs = require('fs');\nconst koa = require('koa');\n\nlet context = null;\nlet uid = 0;\n\nconst app = koa();\n\napp\n  .use(function* (next) {\n    const ctx = this;\n    const id = uid++;\n    const listener = process.createAsyncListener({\n      before: function () {\n        fs.writeSync(1, 'enter ' + id + '\\n');\n        context = ctx;\n      },\n      after: function () {\n        fs.writeSync(1, 'leave ' + id + '\\n');\n        context = null;\n      },\n    });\n    console.log('- add listener %d', id);\n    process.addAsyncListener(listener);\n    context = ctx;\n    yield* next;\n    process.removeAsyncListener(listener);\n    console.log('- removed listener %d', id);\n  })\n  .use(function* (next) {\n    console.log(context ? context.url : 'no context');\n    yield new Promise(function (resolve) {\n      setTimeout(function () {\n        resolve();\n      });\n    });\n    console.log(context ? context.url : 'no context');\n    yield* next;\n  })\n  .use(function* () {\n    this.body = 'foobar';\n  });\n\napp.listen(3000);\n```\n\nThe expected output (for an http req) would be (as far as i understand the concept of asynclisteners):\n\n```\n- add listener 0\n/\nenter 0\nleave 0\n...\nenter 0\n/\n- removed listener 0\n```\n\nBut the actual output shows, that for subsequent request, the previous callbacks are called too (i don't know why):\n\n```\n- add listener 1\n/\nenter 0\nleave 0\nenter 0\nenter 1\nleave 0\nleave 1\nenter 0\nenter 1\nleave 0\nleave 1\nenter 0\nenter 1\n/\n- removed listener 1\nleave 0\nleave 1\nenter 0\nenter 1\nleave 0\nleave 1\nenter 0\nleave 0\nenter 0\nleave 0\nenter 0\nleave 0\nenter 0\nleave 0\n```\n\nIf I put some `console.log` statements in `glue.js` after https://github.com/othiym23/async-listener/blob/master/glue.js#L481 It shows that the listeners are not removed.\n\nIt's _really_ interesing, but if I put a `console.log` statement to https://github.com/othiym23/async-listener/blob/master/glue.js#L471, the listeners _are_ removed correctly:\n\n``` js\nif (!registered) listeners.push(listener);\nconsole.log('after add, listeners: %d', listeners.length);\n// require('fs').writeSync(1, 'after add, listeners: ' + listeners.length + '\\n');\nreturn listener;\n```\n\nPutting `console.log` after `process.addAsyncListener` call won't work. Using `fs.writeSync` instead of `console.log` also doesn't change the behavior.\n\nUnfortunately, this `console.log` call breaks the expected asyncListener behavior:\n\n```\nafter add, listeners: 1 // i guess this is logged because of promise inspection?\nafter remove, listeners: 0\n- add listener 0 // console.log call in my example middleware\nafter add, listeners: 1 // console.log call in addAsyncListener in glue.js\n/\nenter 0\nleave 0\nenter 0\nleave 0\nenter 0\nleave 0\nno context // <-- this should print /\nafter remove, listeners: 0 // console.log call in removeAsyncListener in glue.js\n- removed listener 0 // console.log call in my example middleware\nenter 0\nleave 0\n- add listener 1\nafter add, listeners: 1\n/\nenter 1\nleave 1\nenter 1\nleave 1\nenter 1\nleave 1\nno context\nafter remove, listeners: 0\n- removed listener 1\nenter 1\nleave 1\n- add listener 2\nafter add, listeners: 1\n/\nenter 2\nleave 2\nenter 2\nleave 2\nenter 2\nleave 2\nno context\nafter remove, listeners: 0\n- removed listener 2\nenter 2\nleave 2\n```\n\nWithout `enter/leave`:\n\n```\nafter add, listeners: 1\nafter remove, listeners: 0\n- add listener 0\nafter add, listeners: 1\n/\nno context // <- this should print /\nafter remove, listeners: 0 // listeners are removed correctly\n- removed listener 0\n- add listener 1\nafter add, listeners: 1\n/\nno context\nafter remove, listeners: 0\n- removed listener 1\n- add listener 2\nafter add, listeners: 1\n/\nno context\nafter remove, listeners: 0\n- removed listener 2\n```\n\nIf I change the `console.log('after add, listeners: %d', listeners.length)` to `writeSync(1, 'after add, listeners: ' + listeners.length + '\\n')`:\n\n```\nafter add, listeners: 1\nafter remove, listeners: 0\n- add listener 0\nafter add, listeners: 1\n/\n/ // <- output is fine\nafter remove, listeners: 0 // listener is removed?\n- removed listener 0\n- add listener 1\nafter add, listeners: 2 // the first listener is still there?\n/\n/\nafter remove, listeners: 1\n- removed listener 1\n- add listener 2\nafter add, listeners: 3\n/\n/\nafter remove, listeners: 2\n- removed listener 2\n```\n\n The `listeners` array keeps growing, up to 26 items.\n\nMaybe I'm doing something wrong, but for me it seems that this is a bug :smile: \n",

                         {
                              "title": "net.Server gets onconnection callback wrapped before a handle has been assigned",
                              "description": "There is a race condition that the polyfill doesn't take into account, which is that even after Servers are created and `server._listen2()` is called, the libuv handle may not be assigned to the object yet, causing the wrapping to crash. Just testing on whether the handle is set isn't enough, because that means that a callback chain may not be properly wrapped; a better solution will need to delay wrapping until the handle is known to have been assigned.\n\nThis bug is the cause for newrelic/node-newrelic#54, and probably some other crashes like it we've seen in the past.\n",

                              "title": "fix value in the callback when new value is a child object of an old value",
                              "description": "When objects being replaced on the observed graph, old object and all of its subgraph is being revoked and new object becomes cloned and observable.\r\n\r\nIn case when new value is child of an old value, in the callback the new value appears to be non-usable revoked proxy. See flow below.\r\nThis affects callbacks only, the values on the observed graph itself are okay.\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nlet g = {\r\n    a: {\r\n        b: {\r\n            prop: 'text'\r\n        },\r\n        prop: 'text'\r\n    }\r\n};\r\nlet og = Observable.from(g);\r\nog.observe(changes => {\r\n    changes[0].value.prop === 'text';        // at this point an error is thrown\r\n});\r\n\r\nog.a = og.a.b;\r\n\r\nog.a.prop === 'text';            // this is fine, only the value within the callback is affected\r\n```",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2019-01-28T07:30:24Z",

                         {
                              "title": "Object references",
                              "description": "if you do this with standard object:\r\nvar t={a:{},b:{}}\r\nundefined\r\nt.a.c='i'\r\n\"i\"\r\nt.b=t.a\r\n{c: \"i\"}\r\nt.a.c\r\n\"i\"\r\nt.b.c\r\n\"i\"\r\nt.a.c='o'\r\n\"o\"\r\nt.a.c\r\n\"o\"\r\nt.b.c\r\n\"o\"\r\n\r\nwith your object observer you will see that t.b.c. will be \"i\".\r\nBecause when you do t.b=t.a you clone t.a.\r\nI think in this case we don't need to clone but to add another parent to the observer.\r\nIt will complicate a lot the code but it will be as close as possible to a standard js object\r\nThank you.\r\nps I think your work is huge\r\nps2 revoke oldvalue after deliver the changes because if newvalue is a child of oldvalue it will throw an error",

                         {
                              "title": "update lru-cache to 7.3.1",
                              "description": "There's a pretty serious bug that occurs if the list gets reordered during the initial fill.  Definitely upgrade to 7.3.1 asap.  (7.3.0 is deprecated.)",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-02-10T00:03:45Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-02-10T14:43:55Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-02-10T14:43:55Z",
                              "commentCount": 1
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "[BUG] potential security issue: sending cookies to wrong origin over redirect",
                              "description": "(I could not find a more specific place to file security issues; I'm sorry if this was the wrong place.)\r\n\r\n# What / Why\r\n\r\n`make-fetch-happen` contains [code to strip `authorization` headers](https://github.com/npm/make-fetch-happen/blob/ff3d03c7828bb029de556c5df1714e30c173c81e/lib/fetch.js#L56-L57) upon redirect to hosts other than the originally requested host.\r\n\r\nA [recently-reported CVE in `node-fetch`](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-0235) (a different package that `make-fetch-happen` does not depend on) fixes that package to contain similar logic. However, the `node-fetch` logic also strips the `cookie` and `cookie2` headers (plus the `www-authenticate` header, which seems odd because that is a server->client header).\r\n\r\nThis means that any cookies sent with the request in `make-fetch-happen` will be sent to the redirect target site, even if it has a different request/origin. Certainly this is not a great match for what happens in the browser, as browser cookies are origin-specific. So it seems like this may be a bug/security issue in `make-fetch-happen` and that it should strip `cookie` (and I guess `cookie2`) on cross-domain redirects.\r\n\r\n## When\r\n\r\nRun this code:\r\n\r\n```\r\nimport fetch from \"make-fetch-happen\";\r\nimport { createServer } from \"http\";\r\n\r\nconst redirectTargetServer = createServer((req, res) => {\r\n  console.log(\"Redirect request Authorization\", req.headers.authorization);\r\n  console.log(\"Redirect request Cookie\", req.headers.cookie);\r\n  res.writeHead(200);\r\n  res.end();\r\n});\r\n\r\nredirectTargetServer.listen(0, () => {\r\n  const redirectTargetPort = redirectTargetServer.address().port;\r\n\r\n  const redirectSourceServer = createServer((req, res) => {\r\n    console.log(\"Original request Authorization\", req.headers.authorization);\r\n    console.log(\"Original request Cookie\", req.headers.cookie);\r\n    // We redirect to 127.0.0.1 but make the original request to localhost, so that\r\n    // the domain names differ.\r\n    res.writeHead(302, { Location: `http://127.0.0.1:${redirectTargetPort}` });\r\n    res.end();\r\n  });\r\n\r\n  redirectSourceServer.listen(0, async () => {\r\n    console.log(\"Sending request\");\r\n    await fetch(`http://localhost:${redirectSourceServer.address().port}`, {\r\n      headers: { Authorization: \"auth\", Cookie: \"cook\" },\r\n    });\r\n    process.exit(0);\r\n  });\r\n});\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt prints:\r\n\r\n```\r\nSending request\r\nOriginal request Authorization auth\r\nOriginal request Cookie cook\r\nRedirect request Authorization undefined\r\nRedirect request Cookie cook\r\n```\r\n\r\nYou can see that Authorization is stripped on redirect and Cookie is not. (Note that the reproduction deliberately uses `localhost` for the initial request and `127.0.0.1` for the redirect target; if your system doesn't support connecting to those two names then it may not work.)\r\n\r\n## Where\r\n\r\nAll versions of make-fetch-happen\r\n\r\n## How\r\n\r\n### Current Behavior\r\n\r\n`authorization` but not `cookie` is stripped for cross-domain redirects\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce\r\n\r\nSee above\r\n\r\n### Expected Behavior\r\n\r\n`cookie` should probably be stripped too\r\n\r\n## Who\r\n\r\nNot sure what this means\r\n\r\n## References\r\n\r\nhttps://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-0235\r\nhttps://github.com/node-fetch/node-fetch/pull/1449",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-01-18T20:51:13Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-01-19T22:42:22Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-01-25T18:20:20Z",
                              "commentCount": 4
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "[BUG] running `cacache.verify` resets cache time and will result in stale responses",
                              "description": "# What / Why\r\nRunning `cacache.verify` does a full cache rebuild and resets `entry.time`. This will result in stale responses, because `make-fetch-happen` considers `entry.time` to be time-of-fetch.\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce\r\n- fetch something\r\n- wait until response is considered stale\r\n- call `cacache.verify`\r\n- fetch something again -> is a cache hit\r\n\r\n### Expected Behavior\r\n- fetch something again -> is a cache miss\r\n\r\n### Possible solution\r\nadd a field to `entry.metadata` to represent time-of-fetch.\r\n\r\n## References\r\n- https://github.com/npm/cacache/tree/latest#--cacacheverifycache-opts---promise\r\n- https://github.com/npm/cacache/blob/latest/lib/verify.js#L245\r\n",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2021-07-07T09:23:23Z",
                              "closedAt": "2021-07-15T17:49:34Z",
                              "lastComment": "",
                              "commentCount": 0
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "[BUG] be more resilient to cache read errors",
                              "description": "# What / Why\r\n<!-- Describe the request in detail -->\r\nRight now if an error arises attempting to read from cacache by digest we simply return the error to the user. We need to handle failures when reading content from cacache much more gracefully, likely by removing the index that pointed to the missing or corrupt data as well as the data itself and treating the request as though it was a cache miss.\r\n\r\n## References\r\n<!-- Examples\r\n  * Related to #0\r\n  * Depends on #0\r\n  * Blocked by #0\r\n-->\r\nRelated to https://github.com/npm/arborist/pull/297\r\n",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",

                              "closedAt": "2021-07-15T17:48:42Z",
                              "lastComment": "",
                              "commentCount": 0
                         },

Neither `CHANGELOG.md` nor `README.md` describe what has changed.\r\n\r\n## When\r\n\r\n* when v9.0.0+ was released\r\n\r\n## Where\r\n\r\n  * npm/make-fetch-happen\r\n\r\n## How\r\n\r\n* nobody documented the change\r\n\r\n### Current Behavior\r\n\r\n* Change log only describes up to version 8.0.3\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce\r\n\r\n* Look here: https://github.com/npm/make-fetch-happen/blob/latest/CHANGELOG.md\r\n\r\n### Expected Behavior\r\n\r\n* See what changed so that I know if my code will break or not when I upgrade.\r\n\r\n## Who\r\n\r\n* n/a\r\n\r\n## References\r\n\r\n* n/a\r\n",

                         {
                              "title": "[BUG] `getAuth` is not aware of url-encoded characters",
                              "description": "# What / Why\r\nWhen using a proxy with authentication, the module will use `getProxyUri` https://github.com/npm/make-fetch-happen/blob/707222a590168c4cf4c875ff91733469f774f1fa/agent.js#L137 to parse a specified proxy URL. Since this library does not use the legacy `URL.parse` but the `URL` constructor the URL's `username` and `password` will not be url-decoded. This will lead to erroneous Authorization headers.\r\n\r\nA possible fix would be to use `decodeURIComponent` on both `username` and `password` in `getAuth`: https://github.com/npm/make-fetch-happen/blob/707222a590168c4cf4c875ff91733469f774f1fa/agent.js#L157\r\n\r\n## When\r\n<!-- Examples\r\n  * Whenever I press a button\r\n  * January 1st 2001 @ 12:00pm PST\r\n  * Every day @ 7:00pm PST\r\n  * Every 100 milliseconds\r\n-->\r\n* Whenever a proxy with authorization with url-encoded characters is used\r\n\r\n## Where\r\n<!-- Examples\r\n  * npm enterprise\r\n  * npm public registry\r\n  * npm/<repository>\r\n-->\r\n* n/a\r\n\r\n## How\r\n\r\n### Current Behavior\r\n<!-- Describe how it currently works -->\r\n* The module will set the `auth` properties on the proxy's options with url-encoded charaters.\r\n* for example: `https://test:test%231github.com` will result in `getAuth() -> 'test:test%231'`\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce\r\n<!-- Describe how to produce the issue -->\r\n* Set the `http_proxy` environment variable to an URL with authorization and a valid proxy.\r\n* Make a request and the proxy will answer with 407\r\n\r\n### Expected Behavior\r\n<!-- Describe how it should work -->\r\n* The module will set the `auth` properties on the proxy's options with url-decoded charaters.\r\n* for example: `https://test:test%231github.com` will result in `getAuth() -> 'test:test#1'`\r\n",

                              "title": "[BUG] http redirect makes integrity check failed",
                              "description": "# What / Why\r\n<!-- Describe the request in detail -->\r\n> http redirect like 302 will make integrity check failed\r\n\r\n## Where\r\n<!-- Examples\r\n  * npm enterprise\r\n  * npm public registry\r\n  * npm/<repository>\r\n-->\r\n\r\nFirst it was found in `pacote`, but finally I locate the problem in `make-fetch-happen` package\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce\r\n<!-- Describe how to produce the issue -->\r\n\r\nUse `pacote` with custom registry:\r\n\r\n```js\r\nconst pacote = require( 'pacote' )\r\n\r\npacote.tarball( 'react@16.x', {\r\n  registry: `https://registry.npm.taobao.org`\r\n} ).then( buffer => console.log( 'got it', buffer ) )\r\n```\r\n\r\n## How\r\n\r\nThe root cause is that when requesting the tarball file, it will be 302 redirected to another location by my custom npm registry\r\n\r\ne.g. visit https://registry.npm.taobao.org/react/download/react-16.13.1.tgz, it will be redirected to https://cdn.npm.taobao.org/react/-/react-16.13.1.tgz\r\n\r\nthe 302 request will use the unmatched integrity to do the integrity check, which will fail\r\n\r\n### Current Behavior\r\n<!-- Describe how it currently works -->\r\n\r\nSome error appears\r\n\r\n```\r\nsha1-xxx integrity checksum failed when using sha1: wanted sha1-yyy\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Expected Behavior\r\n<!-- Describe how it should work -->\r\n\r\nNo Error\r\n",

                         {
                              "title": "[BUG] long npm install duration due to huge cacache entries",
                              "description": "# What / Why\r\n\r\nI have a cron job that runs every 5 minutes. It runs `npm install -g git3po`. And I've noticed that over time, this process is taking longer to complete. When re-running the same command manually, it takes 81 seconds to complete. For much of that time, I see \"checking installable status\" on screen. \r\n\r\nRunning the same install with --verbose gives me the following output.... you can tell by the timestamps that each dependency takes ~1 second:\r\n\r\n<details>\r\n\r\n```\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/lodash 7882ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/bluebird 8572ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/superagent 9271ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/chrono-node 9977ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/colors 12032ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/debug 12032ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/babel-runtime 12037ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/yargs 13436ms (from cache)\r\nnpm http fetch GET 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/js-yaml 13444ms (from cache)\r\n```\r\n\r\n</details>\r\n\r\nI debugged this some, though not completely. It appears to reside in how make-fetch-happen leverages cacache. Here's what I saw in the cpu profile:\r\n\r\n![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39191/85182854-c7525680-b23e-11ea-99c7-d65037cf8a53.png)\r\n\r\nAnd zooming in:\r\n<img width=\"1661\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-06-19 at 2 19 48 PM\" src=\"https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39191/85182866-d0dbbe80-b23e-11ea-808b-b7bc7fed48c8.png\">\r\n\r\nIt's the [`cacache.get.info(this._path, key)`](https://github.com/npm/make-fetch-happen/blob/b04c4c16a7bb99ff2df1a3ee8ac5b738a43a1a30/cache.js#L42) call from m-f-s that results in the big latency. And why? Because I apparently have ~16,000 entries for some of my buckets. (That's 23MB of text) :) Doing some back-of-the-envelope math, if I have a new entry every 5 minutes, that'd be ~57 days ago, which seems roughly when I last noticed this and ended up doing `npm cache clean --force` (which did indeed resolve the problem).\r\n\r\nJust for a sense of scale, my `~/.npm/cacache/index-v5` folder is now 2.8 GB. And I've confirmed it's only just the typical cacache text files in there.\r\n\r\nSo on the plus side, it doesn't appear I have a lot of duplicate files on disk due to smart caching. 🥳  But OTOH, the cache entries keeping track of all the kinds of requests that were satisfied by this cache entry keep growing.\r\n\r\n\r\nHere's two entries out of the 16k, just for comparison:\r\n![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39191/85183775-d25ab600-b241-11ea-8720-6d8b76b6ec12.png)\r\n\r\n\r\n### Full cache vs empty cache\r\n\r\nTo simulate empty cache I just renamed `~/.npm/cacache/index-v5`.\r\n\r\nFull cache npm install -g duration: 81s\r\nEmpty cache npm install -g duration: 8s\r\n\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce\r\n\r\nI haven't tried it, but I would imagine a script which just runs `git install -g whatever` in a loop would demonstrate the increased latency over time, especially as the entries exceed 10MB.\r\n\r\n-----\r\n\r\n👋 Isaac! Thanks for making this system and keeping it runnin! :D ",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2020-06-19T22:31:57Z",
                              "closedAt": "2021-06-01T19:23:53Z",
                              "lastComment": "",
                              "commentCount": 0
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "[BUG] Response headers missing for 304 responses",
                              "description": "# What / Why\r\n\r\nmake-fetch-happen deviates from browser caching behavior in the following ways:\r\n\r\n1. When a 304 Not Modified response is received, and the cache is used for the response, the headers are missing from the [Response](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Response) object. Note that `.text()` and `.json()` still work on the response object and provide the cached response body -- it's just the headers that are missing.\r\n2. A 304 Not Modified response status should be converted to a 200 before handed off to the user of make-fetch-happen. This is important for the [Response.ok](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Response/ok) property to be true for responses that come from cache.\r\n\r\n## When\r\n\r\nFrom what I can tell, this occurs whenever a server responds with 304 and the cached version of the response is used. Generally, a server will send a 304 due to the `if-modified-since` or `if-none-match` headers.\r\n\r\n## Where\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/systemjs/systemjs, which I help maintain, uses make-fetch-happen. I noticed this when requesting a resource from a webpack-dev-server, which properly responded with a 304 in accordance to the `if-modified-since` and `if-none-match` headers sent by make-fetch-happen.\r\n\r\n## How\r\n\r\n### Current Behavior\r\n\r\nResponses from cache are missing all response headers, indicate that they are not `ok`, and have the wrong HTTP status (304 instead of 200).\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce\r\n\r\nSee https://github.com/joeldenning/make-fetch-happen-304\r\n\r\n### Expected Behavior\r\n\r\nI expected make-fetch-happen to transparently convert the 304 into a 200 response that is `ok`, since that is how browsers implement fetch. If not that, I expected `res.headers.get('content-type')` to work.\r\n\r\n## Who\r\n\r\nMyself and @guybedford are interested in this one\r\n\r\n## References\r\n\r\nSee https://github.com/systemjs/systemjs/pull/2171, where I have employed a workaround for this problem.\r\n",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2020-04-10T02:37:19Z",
                              "closedAt": "2021-06-01T19:23:53Z",
                              "lastComment": "2020-04-10T02:45:41Z",
                              "commentCount": 1
                         },

                         {
                              "title": "cache not working for URLs with params",
                              "description": "<!--\r\n⚠️🚨 BEFORE FILING AN ISSUE: 🚨⚠️\r\n\r\n👉🏼 CONTRIBUTING.md 👈🏼 (the \"contribution guidelines\" up there ☝🏼)\r\n\r\nI PROMISE IT'S A VERY VERY SHORT READ.🙇🏼\r\n-->\r\n\r\nIt seems that the caching is not working to distinguish between URLs which are only different on the URL params, like it might happen with search parameters.  I tried to debug it a little, and it appears that with two URLs which differ only in url parameters, the second URL will overwrite the first, and so when we go back to cacache asking for the first, it won't find it in the cache.  So for systems that are based entirely on query parameters the caching fails on the large majority of requests.\r\n\r\nSo \r\n/a/b/c\r\n/d/e/f \r\nwork\r\n\r\nbut \r\n?a=1&b=3\r\n?a=3&c=4\r\n\r\nwill fail.  Is there a reason that URL params are not added in as part of the cacache key after the URL has been parsed?  If they were part of the key this issue would resolve itself naturally.  This is the current cachedKey from cache.js and it does not include URL Params.  Would it be possible to have those included optionally based on the use case?\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nfunction cacheKey (req) {\r\n  const parsed = url.parse(req.url)\r\n  return `make-fetch-happen:request-cache:${\r\n    url.format({\r\n      protocol: parsed.protocol,\r\n      slashes: parsed.slashes,\r\n      host: parsed.host,\r\n      hostname: parsed.hostname,\r\n      pathname: parsed.pathname\r\n    })\r\n  }`\r\n}\r\n```\r\n",

                         {
                              "message": "fix: address data corruption when cache is slow\n\nSomething weird is going on here.  This SHOULD be fine as a simple\npipe(), but for some reason, backpressure from the cache stream can\ncause the pipeline to drop the first chunk of data, resulting in invalid\nJSON.  Until that is fixed, just write into the cache without any\nbackpressure.\n\nThe only hazard is that, if the fs is truly very slow, and the rest of\nthe consumption pipeline is very fast, then we'll back up into memory\nand use more than we ought to, rather than pushing back on the incoming\nstream.  However, this isn't likely to ever be a problem due to how npm\ndoes HTTP.  Either it's fetching a JSON response, or a tarball (which is\nalso either unpacking to disk, or streaming directly to a tarball file\non disk).  So, if the disk is slow, and it's a tarball request, we're\nlikely to get backpressure from the main pipeline anyway.  It can only\nbecome a problem if the JSON response is large enough to span multiple\nchunks, and also the fs is loaded enough to start slowing down.  In the\nJSON response case, we're going to load the whole thing in memory\nanyway, so nothing is made particularly *worse* by this lack of\nbackpressure.\n\nIt is possible that the root cause of this bug exists either in cacache,\nminipass-pipeline, or minipass itself.  But since we don't do a\nmulti-pipe tee stream anywhere else in npm's stack, this is the only\nspot where it can make itself known.\n\nRe: https://github.com/npm/npm-registry-fetch/issues/23",
                              "created_at": "2020-05-04T18:19:14Z",
                              "sha": "7f896bef4bbcab73eccb92b5999204b673cdf485"

                         {
                              "message": "fix(retry): be more specific about when we retry\n\nRetries are now attempted only for specific known errors. All other will\nfail fast. Additionally, requests will be retried on 404s and\nrate-limiting status codes 420 (for Twitter) and 429, along with the\noriginal 408 and 500-level error codes. All other codes will continue to\nfast-path to request failure.\n\nOne big effect of this is that requests are no longer retried on\nENOTFOUND -- that is, the getaddrinfo DNS failure error. When this\nhappens, the problem is almost certainly that the user is currently\noffline. In combination with conditional requests and the cache rules,\nthis means that make-fetch-happen now has effectively an \"offline mode\",\nwhere the `default` cache mode will only fail on ENOTFOUND if there is\nno cache entry available.\n\nAs before, if we're using a stale locally-cached request due to an error\n(again, such as ENOTFOUND), a `Warning: 111` header will be added to the\nresponse, so you can check that field to figure out what\nmake-fetch-happen did.\n\nBREAKING CHANGE: Retry logic has changes.\n\n* 404s, 420s, and 429s all retry now.\n* ENOTFOUND no longer retries.\n* Only ECONNRESET, ECONNREFUSED, EADDRINUSE, ETIMEDOUT, and `request-timeout` errors are retried.",

Linux 3.19.0-66-generic\nnpm ERR! argv \"/home/tylercollier/.nodenv/versions/6.3.1/bin/node\" \"/home/tylercollier/.nodenv/versions/6.3.1/bin/npm\" \"run\" \"build\"\nnpm ERR! node v6.3.1\nnpm ERR! npm  v3.10.5\nnpm ERR! file sh\nnpm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE\nnpm ERR! errno ENOENT\nnpm ERR! syscall spawn\nnpm ERR! redux-act-async@0.15.0 build: `babel src --out-dir lib`\nnpm ERR! spawn ENOENT\nnpm ERR! \nnpm ERR! Failed at the redux-act-async@0.15.0 build script 'babel src --out-dir lib'.\nnpm ERR! Make sure you have the latest version of node.js and npm installed.\nnpm ERR! If you do, this is most likely a problem with the redux-act-async package,\nnpm ERR! not with npm itself.\nnpm ERR! Tell the author that this fails on your system:\nnpm ERR!     babel src --out-dir lib\n```\n\nIt's trying to run `babel`, from the babel-cli package, which I don't have on my production server. The cheater fix is for me to install babel-cli. But I think you should remove the postinstall script, since it seems like it's for dev only? When I look at the package of redux-act-async that's on npm, it already has a `lib` directory with the pre-built/babelfied files there anyway. Or perhaps you can use a prepublish script instead, like is suggested [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/27804645/135101):\n\n```\n{ \n  scripts: {\n    \"prepublish\": \"npm run build\"\n  }\n}\n```\n",

                              "title": "Async callback rows matched vs. rows affected",
                              "description": "**Describe the bug**\r\nMySQL.Async.execute() is supposed to pass rowsAffected to the callback function.\r\nYet it appears to be passing rowsMatched.\r\n\r\n**To Reproduce**\r\n\r\n```\r\nCREATE TABLE foo (id INTEGER, highscore BIGINT DEFAULT 0);\r\nINSERT INTO foo (id) VALUES (1);\r\n```\r\nRun the following from MySQL shell vs. with the library:\r\n```\r\nUPDATE foo SET highscore = greatest(highscore, 1337); -- this is supposed to return 1 rows affected\r\nUPDATE foo SET highscore = greatest(highscore, 42); -- this is supposed to return 0 rows affected (no change)\r\n```\r\nSet up callbackfunction like:\r\n```\r\nfunction(rowsAffected)\r\n    print(rowsAffected)\r\nend\r\n```\r\n\r\n**Expected behavior**\r\nAn output of\r\n```\r\n1\r\n0\r\n```\r\ninstead of\r\n```\r\n1\r\n1\r\n```\r\n\r\n**Software:**\r\n - OS: Debian 10\r\n - Version of the resource: 3.3.2\r\n - Database Version: 10.3.31-MariaDB-0+deb10u1\r\n\r\n**Additional context**\r\nI think the library is returning how many rows were matched, as MySQL Client reports 1 for that.\r\nAlso, I found this line in the [MySQL documentation](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/c-api/8.0/en/mysql-affected-rows.html):\r\n\r\n> For UPDATE statements, the affected-rows value by default is the number of rows actually changed. If you specify the CLIENT_FOUND_ROWS flag to mysql_real_connect() when connecting to mysqld, the affected-rows value is the number of rows “found”; that is, matched by the WHERE clause. \r\n\r\nSo I guess this is the cause? Not sure.\r\n",

                    "issues": [
                         {
                              "title": "[FEATURE] Support sending custom request headers to a registry (`$MY_AUTH_HEADER: $VALUE`)",
                              "description": "If an npm registry is behind a proxy, or a custom registry is used, then a custom header may be required in headers to successfully perform HTTP requests for the resource (e.g. failing with HTTP 401s otherwise)\r\n\r\n- When the proxy for a registry has different authentication from the actual registry, the `Authorization` header would not be sufficient\r\n\r\nA similar request was made for the outdated npm/npm repo, but never implemented: https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/18583 \r\n\r\nIs this something you'd be interested in adding, or accepting PRs for?\r\n\r\n(Sorry if this is the wrong repo for this feature request, this repo's README.md links to a CONTRIBUTING.md that is a 404 and there's only issue templates for bug reports and security vulnerabilities - (EDIT: Just found https://github.com/npm/rfcs when looking at closed feature requests elsewhere))\r\n\r\n## How this could be implemented\r\n\r\nI'd imagine this be similarly able to be scoped to a registry, similar to the always-auth/_authToken settings. \r\n\r\nThe key and value could be split on the first '=' and trimmed, then set the same way as other values in the getHeaders function\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/npm/npm-registry-fetch/blob/42d605cb00986c6775e6ec1732b114e065266ae9/lib/index.js#L211-L242\r\n\r\n- e.g. `//my.private.registry.host.com/registry/path/:_customAuthHeader = My-Auth-Header: abcXYZ123:/==` in a config file used by the npm cli would set `req.headers['My-Auth-Header'] = abcXYZ123:/==` (not familiar with whether this expects escaping or not, it should do what the _auth header does)\r\n\r\n",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-10-13T14:15:28Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-10-13T15:49:50Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-10-13T15:49:50Z",
                              "commentCount": 1
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "[FEATURE] registry-scoped certfile and keyfile options ",
                              "description": "# What\r\n\r\nAdd support for registry-scoped `certfile` and `keyfile` options, e.g.\r\n```json\r\n{\r\n  \"//my.registry.example/npm/:certfile\": \"~/.secret/stuff.crt\",\r\n  \"//my.registry.example/npm/:keyfile\": \"~/.secret/stuff.key\"\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\n# Why\r\n\r\n1. Currently you can only set a `cert` and `key` at the top level, which means it could be used in connections against any registry. If your options are coming from `@npmcli/config`, then there's not a good way to control this. Ideally a client certificate would only be presented to the registry that actually needs it, and you should be able to use different ones depending on the registry.\r\n2. The current `cert` and `key` options are the actual contents of the cert/key, rather than paths to them. If your options are coming from `@npmcli/config`, and the cert/key are auto-generated elsewhere, you need to then keep your use `.npmrc` in sync with that process or specify them as env vars. Both options potentially weaken security (e.g. could be accidentally checked in, `.npmrc` might be readable by other users, key could be extracted from `/proc/<pid>/environ`, etc.).\r\n\r\n# Current Workarounds\r\n\r\n* Specify `npm_config_cert` and `npm_config_key` env vars:\r\n   1. You *also* have to specify some (possibly bogus) credentials due to https://github.com/npm/cli/issues/4765.\r\n   2. If your registry validates the explicit credentials (in addition to mTLS) this may not work\r\n   3. Security concerns (see `Why` section)\r\n* Dynamically generate a temp `.npmrc` with the desired settings and use it via `npm_config_userconfig`:\r\n   1. You *also* have to specify some (possibly bogus) credentials due to https://github.com/npm/cli/issues/4765.\r\n   2. If your registry validates the explicit credentials (in addition to mTLS) this may not work\r\n   3. Security concerns (see `Why` section)\r\n* Spin up a local mTLS proxy to your registry and use it via HTTP_PROXY (or other env/config)\r\n   1. May still require you to specify some (bogus) credentials due to https://github.com/npm/cli/issues/4765.\r\n* Monkey-patch `npm-registry-fetch` to inject the `key`/`cert` as necessary\r\n   1. May still require you to specify some (bogus) credentials, or monkey-patch `@npmcli/config` as well 😅 \r\n\r\nAll the workarounds are problematic, and get even more complicated in dual-publishing scenarios. For example, you might want to scope the (bogus) credentials, but that can't be done via env vars due to [this bug](https://github.com/npm/config/issues/64).\r\n\r\n# Notes\r\n1. I'd be happy to put together PRs around this if the idea is acceptable. A corresponding change would likely also be needed to `getCredentialsByURI`/etc. in `@npmcli/config`\r\n3. This feature is related to #38 and https://github.com/npm/cli/issues/4765 in the sense that these could be considered new authN-related options, i.e. custom registry authN could **solely** be done via mTLS, in which case we shouldn't throw `ENEEDAUTH` if these are set but token/credentials are not.",

                              "title": "[BUG] 30s default timeout is too small",
                              "description": "# What / Why\r\n\r\nSee https://github.com/npm/cli/issues/1151\r\n\r\nThe documented default timeout of 30s was not being set in v4, so we \"fixed the glitch\" in nrf 4.0.3, causing problems for people.\r\n\r\nThere's no npm v6 way to specify what timeout to use, so not having a timeout at all seems like a reasonable default for the v4 line, at least.                          {
                              "message": "feat(auth) load/send based on URI, not registry\n\nBREAKING CHANGE: removes the alwaysAuth config\r\n\r\nThis refactors the handling of auth in the new context where npm/cli\r\nwill _only_ ever send authorization in such a way that any\r\nauthorization-related options are scoped to a given sanitized registry\r\nhost and path.\r\n\r\nThis fixes a troubling situation where a user has intentionally logged\r\ninto two separate registries, one which serves package distribution\r\ntarballs, and the other which has packuments pointing to it.\r\n\r\nFor example, a request to `https://registry.internal/private-thing`\r\nmight return this packument:\r\n\r\n```json\r\n{\r\n  \"name\": \"private-thing\",\r\n  \"dist-tags\": {\r\n    \"latest\": \"1.0.0\"\r\n  },\r\n  \"versions\": {\r\n    \"1.0.0\": {\r\n      \"name\": \"private-thing\",\r\n      \"version\": \"1.0.0\",\r\n      \"dist\": {\r\n        \"tarball\": \"https://tarballs.internal/private-thing-1.0.0.tgz\"\r\n      }\r\n    }\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf the user has properly logged into both `https://registry.internal`\r\nand `https://tarballs.internal` (or at least placed an auth or bearer\r\ntoken in their `.npmrc` for each), then this should work properly when\r\nthey run:\r\n\r\n```\r\nnpm install private-thing --registry=https://registry.internal\r\n```\r\n\r\nHowever, previously the auth for `https://tarballs.internal` would never\r\nbe loaded, because it was being loaded based solely on the _registry_\r\nURI, regardless of the actual URI being fetched, and then only _sent_\r\nwhen the hostname matches, and so the request for the tarball would\r\nfail.\r\n\r\nBREAKING CHANGES:\r\n\r\n* The `alwaysAuth` config is no longer relevant.  If we have\r\n  authentication information for a given URI, we send it when making the\r\n  request to that URI.  This was previously being done based on the\r\n  presence of a `scope` parameter or a scoped `spec` option.  However,\r\n  that is not reliable, as users can depend directly on tarball URLs,\r\n  and other parts of the system may have reason to make requests to the\r\n  registry in question without a specific dependency spec in mind (for\r\n  example, to fetch a packument for the purpose of calculating\r\n  metavulnerabilities during an `npm audit` operation.)\r\n\r\n* A top level `_auth`, `_authToken`, `username`, `_password`, or\r\n  `password` option is no longer respected if not scoped to a given\r\n  registry URL.  This functionality was removed from npm/cli as of\r\n  version 7, due to the risk of sending credentials to an incorrect host\r\n  by mistake.  The npm cli will automatically scope these top-level\r\n  configs to the default registry option and save them back to the\r\n  `.npmrc` file the first time they are encountered, so users generally\r\n  see no disruption, and this change only affects non-npm users of\r\n  npm-registry-fetch.\r\n\r\n* Add 'name' to HttpError classes, canonicalize tap usage\r\n\r\n* Suggest fix for case broken by removing alwaysAuth\r\n\r\nSince we no longer send auth to different registry hosts when alwaysAuth\r\nis set, attempt to get the scoped registry auth when an un-authenticated\r\nrequest fails.  If that scoped registry auth exists, then direct the\r\nuser to a web page that tells them how to fix the problem.",
                              "created_at": "2021-04-22T17:13:30Z",
                              "sha": "cc11cc15c9f457c01159a69ce342dc99dea12456"
                         },

                         {
                              "message": "fix(rudy): export things used in tests",
                              "created_at": "2019-10-23T05:51:30Z",
                              "sha": "17bc948128aa9f5d5c72b78484136e4de05e3915"
                         },
                         {
                              "message": "fix(history): store index of current history stack entry in the browser location state (#61)\n\nPreviously the history stack entries contained only an `id` referring to a history, while the entries and current index were stored in session storage. As in https://github.com/respond-framework/rudy/issues/59, this is not enough information to reliably determine which entry is currently active. For example, when the user uses the browser back/forward buttons (which can travel across multiple history states at once). Here the current index has been moved from the session storage to the state of each browser history entry. Since the combination of session ID and session entry index uniquely identifies and entry, the correct entry can be selected from the saved stack in session storage in all circumstances, given the contents of the current history state which can be read from the browser.\r\n\r\n## Specific changes\r\n- Remove behaviours for browsers not supporting the history API or session storage. They didn't work in the same way, and those browsers are now very very old (e.g. IE9)\r\n- Remove workaround for an edge case where navigating away from the app and back again could cause Rudy to autonomously navigate away from the app a second time. The workaround didn't work in all cases (e.g. if the user manually typed a new URL into the address bar), and is no longer necessary now that the underlying bugs is fixed.\r\n- Remove the behaviour of clearing subsequent entries in the saved history stack when loading the app fresh somewhere in the middle of the stack. The logic underlying this is not sound, because it is possible to traverse multiple entries in the history stack (arriving at entry 2/5 does not mean that entries 3-4 are not still in the future). This way it is still possible for there to be future entries in the rudy/redux state that don't correspond with the browsers future states, but a least navigation will always work correctly. Trying to go forwards via rudy beyond the history entries that the browser agrees with still works, in the sense that it correctly navigates to wherever is next in the browser's history stack (Rudy has no choice about that)\r\n- Replace existing logic to guess the direction/distance of a browser initiated pop now that the correct index is available in the pop state\r\n- Add a new test covering browser initiated pops, including where multiple entries are traversed at once\r\n\r\nBREAKING CHANGE: browsers that don't support the history API or session storage are no longer supported at all. In practice this means IE9 is no longer supported.\r\n\r\nBREAKING CHANGE: future entries in the history stack remain even if the user has since navigated from a previous entry to an external site (because they are no longer removed when they are potentially still the future entries in the browser stack)\r\n\r\nFixes https://github.com/respond-framework/rudy/issues/59",
                              "created_at": "2019-10-16T03:24:32Z",
                              "sha": "3abd2b17de95a6561332c5f3e9d8344ad160e481"

                         {
                              "message": "fix(history): pushing/replacing a route sometimes resulted in a back/next action (#56)\n\nPreviously, actions dispatched by the user to push/replace the route were intercepted and turned into back/next actions if they matched the next or previous entry in the history stack. This meant that it was not possible to push/replace the next/previous route in the history stack. This change removes that behaviour, so that the direction of dispatched actions are preserved.\r\n\r\nBREAKING CHANGE: dispatching a route that matches the previous/next route in the history stack is no longer reinterpreted as a back/next action\r\n\r\nBREAKING CHANGE: history functions `set`/`setParams`/`setState`/`setQuery`/`setHash`/`setBasename` no longer accept a function as an argument\r\n\r\nBREAKING CHANGE: history functions `set`/`setParams`/`setState`/`setQuery` no longer merge their arguments with the existing params/state/query\r\n\r\nBREAKING CHANGE: history functions `back`/`next`/`jump` no longer accept a state argument\r\n\r\nFixes https://github.com/respond-framework/rudy/issues/48",

                              "message": "feat(transformations): Various changes, documentation (#24)\n\nRefactor the code surrounding `fromPath`/`toPath` to fix various issues. Internally, URL encoding is now handled transparently instead of in `toPath`/`fromPath`. The values on the URL side for multi segment parameters are now arrays of strings rather than strings, which makes it a lossless encoding (slashes are now allowed inside segments of multi segment params). The default `toPath` raises exceptions when serializing param values that would not be deserialised the same way (e.g. `null`).                               "description": "## Describe the bug\r\nIf jsoning has written at least one value, and the json file is changed in the file system by a different process, and then `set()` is called with some value, then jsoning overwrites the json file with the previously known values.\r\n\r\n## Reproducible code sample (if applicable)\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nlet db = new jsoning(\"database.json\");\r\ndb.set(\"one\", \"one\");\r\n// Now remove database.json from the file system\r\ndb.set(\"two\", \"two\");\r\n```\r\n\r\n## Expected behavior\r\n\r\nAfter executing the sample code (note the comment about removing the file), the expected behavior would be that database.json contains `{\"two\": \"two\"}`. \r\n\r\nFaulty behavior: The database.json contains `{\"one\": \"one\", \"two\": \"two\"}`.\r\n\r\n## Further details\r\n- Jsoning version: 0.11.21\r\n- Node.js version: v14.17.1\r\n- Operating system: macOS 11.2.3",

                         {
                              "title": "Breaks when using `XMLHttpRequest` directly",
                              "description": "I am using this pattern, for lightweight and compatibility reasons:\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nconst xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();\r\nxhr.open(method, url);\r\nxhr.onload = () => {\r\n  resolve(xhr.response);\r\n};\r\nxhr.send();\r\n```\r\n\r\nWhen using `storybook-addon-mock`, xhr.response is a JSON object, while the native version returns a string - that I later run through JSON.parse.\r\n\r\nI understand that my use-case is the large minority, as there is very little reason to be using both XMLHttpRequest and Storybook. I won't extend the reasons I am using XMLHttpRequest instead of fetch - for example -, but I wanted to report my issue.\r\n\r\nIf someone has a similar issue, here is a quick dirty fix:\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nconst xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();\r\nxhr.open(method, url);\r\nxhr.onload = () => {\r\n  resolve(\r\n    typeof xhr.response === \"string\"\r\n      ? xhr.response\r\n      : JSON.stringify(xhr.response)\r\n  );\r\n};\r\nxhr.send();\r\n```\r\n",

                    "issues": [
                         {
                              "title": "requireFrom pollutes the module cache.",
                              "description": "Say you have a module *foo* that depends on *bar*. If you\r\n\r\n```js\r\nrequire(\"foo\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nAnd then you\r\n\r\n```js\r\nrequire.alias({bar: 42})(\"foo\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt won’t give you a new module *foo* whose value of *bar* is 42; it’ll return the previously-loaded module *foo* with its natural dependency on *bar* because *foo* is already in the modules cache.\r\n\r\nThis was broken by a6859e9 to fix #8. But this was misguided—even though *foo* resolves to the same URL in both cases above, the returned module should be different because its dependencies (*bar*) are different. Possibly we could be clever and try to include the transitive closure of dependencies in the cache key, but it’s much simpler to just have each requireFrom use separate caches.",

                              "createdAt": "2018-08-15T15:38:50Z",

                              "description": "With an endpoint like:\r\n```\r\n        getAction: {\r\n            path: '/:foo',\r\n            verb: 'GET'\r\n        },\r\n```\r\nThe `foo` might include a `/`, or some other (for example`?`), character that would break the API call when made on the client-side but it would work just fine when made on the server-side.\r\n\r\nFor it to work the user would have to encode it first (with `encodeURI` or `encodeURIComponent`) but that would then break the server-side API call because there would be nothing to decode the param in the handler.\r\n\r\nI think that it can be fixed by just encoding the parameters in the module before making the client-side API call but I don't know if there is really a proper way of encoding that would work in all cases. Depending on the use case It's possible to encode \"too much\". For my apps `encodeURIComponent` would be a correct way to encode params but others might need more relaxed `encodeURI` or maybe even something custom so this should likely be customizable.",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",

                         {
                              "title": ".slice has an implementation bug",
                              "description": "Illustrated by #50",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2020-07-23T18:25:24Z",
                              "closedAt": "2020-07-23T23:57:46Z",
                              "lastComment": "2020-07-28T16:17:27Z",
                              "commentCount": 1
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "use a byte sequence instead of a buffer",
                              "description": "imagine how you would go about solving this:\r\n```js\r\nconst File = require('fetch-file') // creates a FIle-like IDL wrapper around fs\r\nconst Blob = require('fetch-blob')\r\n\r\nconst file = File.from('./package.json')\r\nnew Blob([ file ])\r\n```\r\nthe blob's constructor spec says: \r\n  1. Let bytes be an empty [sequence](https://w3c.github.io/FileAPI/#dfn-blobParts) of bytes. (it's not like a long ArrayBuffer holding all data)\r\n  2. For each element in parts:\r\n    1. ...\r\n    2. ...\r\n    3. If element is a Blob, **append the bytes it represents** to bytes.\r\n\r\n2.3 don't say read the the blob and copy the content to a new instance. Beside the fetch-blob can't read the content of the File in a synchronous way to be able to successfully handle the blob parts. so the slicing method is also wrong, it should not `slice` the Buffer like fetch-blob dose today. it should instead update the byte sequences and and create a new offset of where it should start reading stuff from. This also means that arrayBuffer, text and stream is wrong too. `fetch-blob` should instead read each blobPart individually at a later stage to successfully be able to handle the `File` - the constructor should not read the file content.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nwhen you take 2x2 GiB of files from a `<input type=\"file\" multiple>` and concatenate `b = new Blob([fileA, fileB])` then you won't end up with 4 GiB of RAM, it really means that you have a new blob container with two references point to where a snapshot is located. And if you slice it `b.slice(0, -500)` then you have one references to fileA and another reference to fileB with a offset from what it should represent.    `[[start to end of fileA], [start to end minus 500 of fileB]]`\r\n\r\n<img src=\"https://i.stack.imgur.com/cNAud.png\">\r\nimage taken from: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1MOm-8kacXAon1L2tF6VthesNjXgx0fp5AP17L7XDPSM/edit\r\n\r\n_Originally posted by @jimmywarting in https://github.com/node-fetch/node-fetch/issues/835#issuecomment-634648816_\r\n\r\n\r\nthings needs fixing:\r\n- [x] `this[BUFFER]` should be `this[PARTS]` since you can't concatenate all parts\r\n- [x] read methods should loop over all parts and concatenate all parts into one stream/text/arraybuffer and taking the internal offset into consideration\r\n- [x] slicing becomes more complicated since you are now dealing with parts instead of a buffer\r\n  - what really should be done is just copying all parts (clone the blob) and kinda change the internal `this[OFFSET]` from where it should start reading from. \r\n\r\n```js\r\nvar b1 = new Blob([new Uint8Array(1000)])\r\nvar b2 = b1.slice(500) // uses the same parts with an offset=500\r\n// b2 should not take up 500 byte more ram... \r\n```",

                              "createdAt": "2020-06-04T18:04:21Z",
                              "closedAt": "2020-06-07T21:42:43Z",
                              "lastComment": "",
                              "commentCount": 0
                         }

                    "issues": [
                         {
                              "title": "potential bug: `wrap` now autostarting iterators that were previously not autostarted prior to optimisation work",
                              "description": "Placeholder - will try create a minimal example or debug tommorow :)",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-09-13T13:35:13Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-09-21T11:46:28Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-09-21T14:41:09Z",
                              "commentCount": 17
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "Discussion: Destroy propagation in callback-based TransformIterator",
                              "description": "I don't think it's really a bug, but nevertheless, I think it deserves some discussion.\r\n\r\nYesterday, I discover some edge-cases in which chained iterators would keep on running (due to an infinite iterator in the chain), even though the head of the chain was destroyed.\r\nWhile destroy calls should be propagated (unless `destroySource` is set to `false`), this was not happening in this case.\r\n\r\nThe root cause of these problems seemed to be caused by TransformIterators with an (async) callback-based reference to another iterator, where this iterator was created externally.\r\n\r\nThey shared the following form:\r\n```js\r\nconst baseIterator = ...; // Some iterator that has to be created beforehand, and can not be placed in the async callback below.\r\n\r\nconst transformIt = new TransformIterator(async() => baseIterator.map(...), { autoStart: false });\r\n```\r\n\r\nIn cases where `transformIt` (or some other iterator in the chain from `transformIt`) was destroyed **before it was being read**, `baseIterator` would not be destroyed.\r\nThis makes sense of course, because the callback in the `TransformIterator` is never invoked, which breaks the destroy call chain `baseIterator`.\r\n\r\nI've created [a workaround](https://github.com/comunica/comunica/commit/715b8acc122d28d09cbe28c02a1c7b8a7b82d024#diff-a8fdf612bb43b4fd972a47e1661e108b187feae2a73934f74c293b906f54b55c) for these cases, so the problem is solved on my end.\r\nBut I thought it would be good to raise this issue here as well. Perhaps it can help someone with debugging in the future.",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2022-08-18T11:30:11Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-11-14T11:11:55Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-11-14T11:11:55Z",
                              "commentCount": 5
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "Current task scheduler does not guarantee order",
                              "description": "The snippet at https://github.com/RubenVerborgh/AsyncIterator/blob/668697c568484881f663b786e0b6a037c2cd5ab3/taskscheduler.ts#L13-L21 can result in out-of-order execution when a microtask is scheduled before `setTimeout` has occurred.",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2021-06-17T14:13:45Z",
                              "closedAt": "2021-07-22T07:35:23Z",
                              "lastComment": "2021-07-22T07:35:27Z",
                              "commentCount": 3
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "Cloning not inheriting autoStart: false",

                              "title": "Multiple instances of MWSAdvanced overwrite one another",
                              "description": "I'm trying to fetch a report in multiple regions. I do this by creating multiple MWS objects. However, the MWS objects seem to overwrite eachother when I create them using an asynchronous function. \r\n\r\nBelow I wrote some code to give you an example of what I try to do.\r\n\r\n````\r\nconst MWS = require('mws-advanced).MWSAdvanced;\r\n\r\nfunction getKeys(region) {\r\n    switch (region) {\r\n        case \"JP\":\r\n            return {\r\n               //some keys for JP\r\n            }\r\n        default:\r\n            return {\r\n                 //some keys for US\r\n            }\r\n    }\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\nasync function createMWSConnection ({accessKeyId, secretAccessKey, merchantId}) {\r\n    const mws = new MWS({\r\n        accessKeyId,\r\n        secretAccessKey,\r\n        merchantId,\r\n    });\r\n\r\n  // some async stuff here..\r\n\r\n  return mws;\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst requestedReports = [\"JP\", \"NA\"].map(regionCode => {\r\n    const keys = getKeys(regionCode);\r\n    const mws = await createMWSConnection(keys);\r\n    return mws.requestReport( .... SOME OPTIONS HERE .... );\r\n}    \r\n`````\r\n\r\nDoes this code make sense? I think the problem could be here: \r\n````\r\nfunction requestPromise(requestData, opt = {}) {\r\n\treturn new Promise((resolve, reject) => {\r\n\t\t// eslint-disable-line prefer-arrow-callback\r\n\t\tconst mwsInterface = this && this.mws ? this.mws : mws;\r\n                .....\r\n                .....\r\n      }\r\n}\r\n````\r\nIf I console.log the \"this\" object, then \"this\" is undefined. So 'mwsInterface' is set equal to 'mws'. I think that by running my code, the global mws object get overwritten by the second request. Hence, when I try to fetch data from one marketplace I try to do that using the mws object of the second marketplace. What do you think? What else could have caused the behaviour that I'm describing? Is this a bug or is this my own codes wrong doing?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n",

                         {
                              "title": "listOrderItems returns object instead of an array",
                              "description": "The API call to listOrderItems returns an object if there are multiple items in an order. \r\n\r\n**Output:**\r\n```` \r\n{\r\n   \"0\" : {\r\n       OrderItem_ 1\r\n    },\r\n    \"1\": {\r\n        OrderItem_2 \r\n    }\r\n    isGift: \"someval\"\r\n    quantityOrdered: \"someval\"\r\n    quantityShipped: \"someval\"\r\n    productInfo: \"someval\"\r\n}\r\n````\r\nWhere OrderItem_1 and OrderItem_2 are objects in line with the MWS documentation regarding OrderItem: https://docs.developer.amazonservices.com/en_UK/orders-2013-09-01/Orders_Datatypes.html#OrderItem .\r\n\r\n**Expected:**\r\n````\r\n[ {OrderItem_1}, {OrderItem_2}]\r\n````\r\n\r\nI did some digging and I found that the input to the function `parseOrderItems` in orderItems.js does not meet the expected input. The argument `orderItemsList` of this function retrieves the following:\r\n\r\n````\r\nconst parseOrderItems = orderItemsList => {\r\n\tconst { NextToken: nextToken, AmazonOrderId: orderId } = orderItemsList;\r\n\tconsole.log(JSON.stringify(orderItemsList, null, 4));\r\n        ....\r\n        ....\r\n````\r\n\r\n**The above outputs:** \r\n````\r\n{\r\n    \"OrderItems\": {\r\n        \"OrderItem\": [\r\n            {OrderItem_1},\r\n            {OrderItem_2}\r\n         ]\r\n    }\r\n}\r\n````\r\n\r\n**Perhaps this should be/expected:** \r\n````\r\n{\r\n    \"OrderItems\": [{\r\n        \"OrderItem\": OrderItem_1,\r\n        \"OrderItem\": OrderItem_2\r\n    }]\r\n}\r\n\r\nOR: \r\n\r\n{\r\n    \"OrderItems\": [\r\n        OrderItem_1,\r\n        OrderItem_2\r\n    ]\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n````\r\n\r\nI think I found where the error arises, but I don't know how to fix this... Where should I dig next in order to solve this issue? How could this issue be solved?",

                         {
                              "message": "throttle handling v0.0.1\n\n- in conjunction with update to mws-simple 2.1.0, providing an easily\n  machine readable error code, we can now detect throttling correctly\n  at the higher level.\n- super simple version to begin with:\n  when callEndpoint receives a throttle message (503 error from mws), it\n  will sleep() for the amount of time that it would take for you to receive\n  your full amount of calls that were throttled (\"maxInFlight\"), and then\n  it will re-try any requests that were throttled.\n- You don't have to do anything special. Just use async/await or Promises\n  as you should be, and your requests will automatically work with the\n  throttling\n- Obviously, there's lots of room to improve this.\n- callEndpoint now receives the throttle information, by way of\n  generateEndpoints\n- fixed orders category to all have correct restoreRate definitions,\n  where restoreRate is the number of requests you get restored per minute.\n- doc updates",

                         {
                              "title": "Bug: Validation fails with exclusiveMinimum / exclusiveMaximum in schema",
                              "description": "Version 3.1.1\r\n\r\nfails with exclusiveMaximum active:\r\n\r\n```\r\n        myProperty:\r\n          type: number\r\n          minimum: 0.0\r\n          maximum: 360.0\r\n    # TODO     exclusiveMaximum: true\r\n          example: 10.5\r\n```",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2021-11-29T11:28:51Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-05-22T11:50:49Z",
                              "lastComment": "2022-05-22T11:50:49Z",
                              "commentCount": 1
                         },
                         {
                              "title": "Feature: Support for operationId",
                              "description": "Hello,\r\n\r\nIt would be great to add support for validating messages using OperationId in addition to the regular key, channel and operation way. The advantage would be that an operationId is usually immutable after designed while the rest of the parameters could change. For example, sometimes we change the key or the channel name, but (at least the way I design), the operation ID remains the same. This way of doing things is quite useful when using a generated client (such as in OpenAPI), for which the exact channel name would be an implementation detail, with an abstraction layer based on the tag and the operationId.\r\n\r\nThe operationId field is defined in the AsyncAPI specification as an id that \"[...] MUST be unique among all operations described in the API.\" (https://www.asyncapi.com/docs/specifications/2.0.0#fixed-fields-7), so it would be sufficient to search the YAML for the specified ID in order to run the validation.\r\n\r\nProposed implementation:\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\n/**\r\n * Method to validate the Payload against schema definition using an OperationId.\r\n * @param {string} operationId - required - operationId\r\n * @param {Object} payload - required - payload of the message\r\n * @returns {boolean} \r\n */\r\nvalidateByOperationId(operationId, payload);\r\n```\r\n\r\nI'll be glad to submit a PR if the idea is acceptable.\r\n\r\nThanks!",
                              "label": "unlabeledBug",
                              "createdAt": "2020-11-02T21:24:41Z",
                              "closedAt": "2022-05-22T12:02:54Z",
                              "lastComment": "2020-11-03T22:13:27Z",
                              "commentCount": 3

                         {
                              "message": "Bug fix: Fix types.d.ts outputs for nested custom typedefs\n\nI'm not exactly sure why, but it seems any type references to the custom `@typedef` entries that are nested inside other `@typedef` entries fail to be parsed correctly by typescript, and end up with `any` as the type instead. e.g. `MockResponseConfig.dynamicResponseModFn == any` and `DynamicResponseModFn.request == any`. Idk if it's the fact that the declarations are nested inside a module/namespace or what, but none of the my work-around attempts worked (extracting them out of the function scope, unmarking them as `@member`, unmarking everything as `@member`, and all sorts of various tsconfig.json config field changes).\n\nThis meant that they had to be extracted to a separate file. But even if that helped generate the right type for a nested field, it still removed the JSDoc from them (even if tsconfig.json had `removeComments: false` and`importsNotUsedAsValues: \"preserve\"`). This would make IDE autocompletion way less helpful than it could've been (e.g. we should definitely tell the user what default values are and what exactly the purpose of the fields are).\n\nThus, the only acceptable solution was to move them to their own typescript file so that both the nested types and JSDoc would both be accurate. Of course, this hides them from the tsconfig.src.json parsing (even if changing configs like `include`, `files`, `typeRoots`). Since triple slash references (like `/// <reference path=\"./types.ts\" />`) are ignored in `compilerOptions.module != 'AMD|System'`, they have to be imported in the src file itself so that they're properly injected into the final output types.d.ts file.\n\nLong story short, I need to not do this manually. So a future TODO: either add a `ts-loader`/config entry to webpack.config.js, or convert the entire codebase to typescript.",

                         {
                              "title": "Cancelling a POST with a string body generates an asynchronous uncaught error",
                              "description": "**Description**\r\nWhen doing a POST request with a string passed in as the `body`, helix-fetch internally converts it to a Readable stream. When an ongoing request is aborted, the body stream is destroyed, sending along an error. The code that normalizes the `body` to a Readable stream adds a handler for the 'error' event, but currently does so *only when the original `body` was a Readable stream*. So if the original `body` is e.g. a string, then the Readable stream version of it will not have an error handler, and aborting the request will cause it to emit an 'error' event which is never caught, causing e.g. tests of the functionality to fail.\r\n\r\n**To Reproduce**\r\nSteps to reproduce the behavior:\r\n1. run a test where you perform a POST fetch with string data\r\n2. abort the request\r\n3. get an error about an uncaught error, which happens after the test has already finished (this is because destroying the Readable stream schedules the error event on the next tick)\r\n\r\n**Expected behavior**\r\nThe error should be caught (or not emitted at all).\r\n",

                              "title": "Regression: location header is made absolute with redirect=manual",
                              "description": "**Description**\r\nfetching a redirect response manually should not alter the location header. but since v2, it is made absolute.\r\n\r\neg:\r\n\r\n```\r\n$ curl -sD - 'https://httpbingo.org/redirect-to?url=/foo.html'\r\nHTTP/2 302\r\naccess-control-allow-credentials: true\r\naccess-control-allow-origin: *\r\nlocation: /foo.html\r\ndate: Thu, 04 Feb 2021 03:10:22 GMT\r\ncontent-length: 0\r\nserver: Fly/7226d36 (2021-01-25)\r\nvia: 2 fly.io\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nbut with fetch:\r\n\r\n```js\r\n    it('supports redirect: manual with path location', async () => {\r\n      const resp = await fetch(`${protocol}://httpbingo.org/redirect-to?url=/foo.html&status_code=307`, { redirect: 'manual', cache: 'no-store' });\r\n      assert.strictEqual(resp.status, 307);\r\n      assert.strictEqual(resp.headers.get('location'), '/foo.html');\r\n      assert.strictEqual(resp.redirected, false);\r\n    });\r\n```\r\n\r\n```\r\nAssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: Expected values to be strictly equal:\r\n+ actual - expected\r\n\r\n+ 'http://httpbingo.org/foo.html'\r\n- '/foo.html'\r\nExpected :/foo.html\r\nActual   :http://httpbingo.org/foo.html\r\n```\r\n\r\n**To Reproduce**\r\nsee failing test in: https://github.com/adobe/helix-fetch/pull/130\r\n",

                              "title": "Redirected POST is not supported",
                              "description": "**Description**\r\n`POST` requests which are redirected by the server fail with an error.\r\n\r\n**To Reproduce**\r\n```javascript\r\nconst method = 'POST';\r\nconst json = { foo: 'bar' };\r\nconst resp = await fetch('https://httpstat.us/307', { method, json });\r\n// => Error: URL got redirected to https://httpstat.us/, which 'fetch-h2' doesn't support for POST\r\n```\r\n\r\n**Expected behavior**\r\n`POST` requests should be redirected.\r\n\r\n**Workaround**\r\n```javascript\r\nconst method = 'POST';\r\nconst json = { foo: 'bar' };\r\nlet resp = await fetch('https://httpstat.us/307', { method, json, redirect: 'manual' });\r\nif (resp.status === 307) {\r\n  resp = await fetch(resp.headers.get('location'), { method, json, redirect: 'manual' });\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\n**Additional context**\r\nKnown limitation of underlying [fetch-h2](https://github.com/grantila/fetch-h2) implementation.\r\n",

               "creationDate": "2019-01-11",

                    "JavaScript": 77668
               },
               "stars": 24,
               "issues": {
                    "incomplete_results": false,
                    "status_code": "200",
                    "total_bug_issues": 16,
                    "total_issues": 60,
                    "issues": [
                         {
                              "title": "No clear explanation on how to call stored procedure. Not receiving output.",
                              "description": "<!--\r\nThank you for reporting a possible bug in idb-pconnector.\r\n\r\nPlease fill in as much of the template below as you can.\r\n\r\nNode.js version: output of `node -v`\r\nidb-connector version: output of `npm ls idb-connector`\r\nidb-pconnector version: output of `npm ls idb-pconnector`\r\nIBM i version: output of `uname -vr`\r\n\r\n```\r\n  var query = \"CALL @lib3.SONICPAYA(?,?,?,?)\";\r\n  var success = false;\r\n  var out = '';\r\n  var params = ['1', '5', '1', ''];\r\n\r\n  query = query.replace('@lib3', config.library3);\r\n\r\n  DB.runQueryProtected(query, params, function (err, result, data) {\r\n    if (result) {\r\n      success = true;\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    callback(err, data, success, data);\r\n  });\r\n\r\nmodule.exports.runQueryProtected = async function (query, params, callback) {\r\n    var db = require('idb-connector');\r\n    const dbconn = new db.dbconn();\r\n    dbconn.conn(config.db_name);\r\n    const stmt = new db.dbstmt(dbconn);\r\n\r\n      try {\r\n        stmt.prepare(query, function (err) {\r\n          if (err) {\r\n            console.log(err);\r\n          }\r\n\r\n          stmt.bindParameters(params, function (err) {\r\n            if (err) {\r\n              console.log(err);\r\n            }\r\n\r\n            stmt.execute((output, err) => { // output should be an array of output params.\r\n              console.log(err);\r\n              console.log(query, params);\r\n              console.log('OUTPUT:', output);                               "title": "DBPool 'new connection' event emitter issues",
                              "description": "<!--\r\nThank you for reporting a possible bug in idb-pconnector.\r\n\r\nPlease fill in as much of the template below as you can.\r\n\r\nNode.js version:
