`connection.debug(true)`\r\n-->\r\n\r\n**Please complete the following information:**\r\n- Node.js version: v12.16.2\r\n- idb-connector version: 1.2.8\r\n- idb-pconnector version: 1.1.0 (latest master)\r\n- IBM i version: 7.2\r\n\r\n**Describe the bug**\r\n\r\nPerforming library list setup within the `'new connection'` event handler has a synchronization issue.\r\n \r\n**To Reproduce**\r\nSteps to reproduce the behavior:\r\n\r\n```js\r\nconst { DBPool } = require('idb-pconnector');\r\n\r\nasync function setLibListExample() {\r\n  const pool = new DBPool({ url: '*LOCAL' }, { incrementSize: 3, debug: true });\r\n\r\n  pool.on('new connection', async (connection) => {\r\n    await connection.setLibraryList(['QIWS', 'QXMLSERV']);\r\n  });\r\n\r\n  pool.attach();\r\n\r\n  const results = await pool.runSql('SELECT * FROM QCUSTCDT');\r\n console.log(`results:\\n ${JSON.stringify(results)}`);\r\n}\r\n\r\nsetLibListExample().catch((error) => {\r\n  throw error;\r\n  console.error(error);\r\n});\r\n```\r\n**Output**\r\n```\r\nInitializing the pool\r\nCreating Connection 0...\r\nSetConnAttr() attr = 10004, value = 1, rc = 0\r\nConnection 0 created\r\nCreating Connection 1...\r\nSetConnAttr() attr = 10004, value = 1, rc = 0\r\nConnection 1 created\r\nCreating Connection 2...\r\nSetConnAttr() attr = 10004, value = 1, rc = 0\r\nConnection 2 created\r\nFinding available Connection...\r\nConnection 1 found\r\nExecuting SQL...\r\nSQL Statement: SELECT * FROM QCUSTCDT\r\nSQLExecDirect(-1): SELECT * FROM QCUSTCDT\r\nSQLExecDirect(0): CALL QSYS2.QCMDEXC('CHGLIBL LIBL(QIWS QXMLSERV)')\r\nSQLNUMRESULTSCOLS(0) Column Count = 0\r\nDetaching Connection 1...\r\nSQLFreeStmt: stmth 5 [SQL_DROP]\r\nSQLFreeStmt(0)\r\nConnection 1 detached\r\nError: runSql: Failed to exec()\r\n    at ../node_modules/idb-pconnector/lib/dbPool.js:219:18\r\n    at async DBPool.runSql (../node_modules/idb-pconnector/lib/dbPool.js:217:17)\r\n    at async setLibListExample (../event-test.js:12:19)\r\nCaused By:\r\n Error: SQLSTATE=42704 SQLCODE=-204 QCUSTCDT in *LIBL type *FILE not found.\r\n    at Object.<anonymous> (../node_modules/idb-pconnector/lib/statement.js:135:18)\r\nNO RESULTS: SQLExecDirect() callSQLFreeStmt: stmth 12 [SQL_DROP]\r\nSQLFreeStmt(0)\r\nSQLExecDirect(0): CALL QSYS2.QCMDEXC('CHGLIBL LIBL(QIWS QXMLSERV)')\r\nSQLNUMRESULTSCOLS(0) Column Count = 0\r\nNO RESULTS: SQLExecDirect() callSQLFreeStmt: stmth 11 [SQL_DROP]\r\nSQLFreeStmt(0)\r\nSQLExecDirect(0): CALL QSYS2.QCMDEXC('CHGLIBL LIBL(QIWS QXMLSERV)')\r\nSQLNUMRESULTSCOLS(0) Column Count = 0\r\nNO RESULTS: SQLExecDirect() callSQLFreeStmt: stmth 10 [SQL_DROP]\r\nSQLFreeStmt(0)\r\n```\r\n\r\nAs you can see from the output above setting up the library list occurs after the query. The library list is not setup yet therefore the library containing `QCUSCDT` (QIWS) was not found.\r\n\r\n**Additional context**\r\n\r\nOne solution to get this working properly is to have a user provided function that gets called each time a new connection is created. Like what was proposed in https://github.com/IBM/nodejs-idb-pconnector/issues/46#issuecomment-511555115. I would suggest that this be an async function so that we can `await` the function. Doing this would require `attach` to return a promise though. That would be a breaking change requiring a new major version.\r\n\r\nFor now I think its best we revert 6d9c1935173f3792a6dc7b7ccd92d6c14f813f0b.\r\n\r\nThen add milestones for v2.0.0 to make `attach` return a promise. That way can implement a solution like https://github.com/IBM/nodejs-idb-pconnector/issues/46#issuecomment-511555115.\r\n",

                         {
                              "title": "Need to patch how idb-connector dbstmt, dbconn are deleted in idb-connector.js",
                              "description": "When you have an application that uses both `idb-connector` and `idb-pconnector` packages you can run into dbstmt and dbconn not being available when requiring `idb-connector` in your app.\r\n\r\nI noticed this issue while running one of my sample web apps with latest release of idb-pconnector 1.0.3.\r\n\r\nThis caused by the way dbstmt and dbconn are deleted in [idb-pconnector.js](https://github.com/IBM/nodejs-idb-pconnector/blob/master/lib/idb-pconnector.js)\r\n\r\n## Before Patch\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nconst idb = require('idb-connector');\r\nconst Connection = require('./connection');\r\nconst Statement = require('./statement');\r\nconst DBPool = require('./dbPool');\r\n\r\nmodule.exports.Connection = Connection;\r\nmodule.exports.Statement = Statement;\r\nmodule.exports.DBPool = DBPool;\r\n\r\n// do not export dbstmt and dbconn from idb-connector\r\ndelete idb.dbstmt;\r\ndelete idb.dbconn;\r\n// export constants from idb-connector\r\nmodule.exports = { ...module.exports, ...idb };\r\n```\r\n\r\nThese properties were removed from the required idb-connector object to prevent re-exporting those function in idb-pconnector.\r\n\r\n\r\nInstead the propreties should have been removed from module.exports object which gets a clone of the properties with the spread operator.\r\n\r\n## After Patch\r\n\r\n```javascript\r\nconst idb = require('idb-connector');\r\nconst Connection = require('./connection');\r\nconst Statement = require('./statement');\r\nconst DBPool = require('./dbPool');\r\n\r\nmodule.exports.Connection = Connection;\r\nmodule.exports.Statement = Statement;\r\nmodule.exports.DBPool = DBPool;\r\n\r\n// export constants from idb-connector\r\nmodule.exports = { ...module.exports, ...idb };\r\n\r\n// do not export dbstmt and dbconn from idb-connector\r\ndelete module.exports.dbstmt;\r\ndelete module.exports.dbconn;\r\n```\r\n\r\nI knew that require() function caches modules to speed things up.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhat I did not know is that native addons do not get reloaded when object in the require cache changes. [See this](https://nodejs.org/api/modules.html#modules_require_cache)\r\n\r\nIn any case, by requiring idb-connector in idb-pconnector.js it gets cached then dbstmt and dbconn are deleted from the object.\r\n\r\nif you require idb-connector again somewhere else the cached version without dbstmt and dbconn is returned.\r\n\r\nThis problem can be easily shown in the node REPL\r\n\r\n\r\n## Before Patch \r\n:x:  idb-connector cannot reference dbconn dbstmt\r\n```\r\n> require('idb-pconnector')\r\n{ Connection: [Function: Connection],\r\n  Statement: [Function: Statement],\r\n  DBPool: [Function: DBPool],\r\n  SQL_FALSE: 0,\r\n  SQL_TRUE: 1,\r\n  SQL_NTS: -3,\r\n  SQL_SQLSTATE_SIZE: 5,\r\n  ...\r\n}\r\n> require('idb-connector')\r\n{ SQL_FALSE: 0,\r\n  SQL_TRUE: 1,\r\n  SQL_NTS: -3,\r\n  SQL_SQLSTATE_SIZE: 5,\r\n  ....\r\n}\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\n## After Patch \r\n:heavy_check_mark: idb-connector can reference dbstmt dbconn\r\n```\r\n{ Connection: [Function: Connection],\r\n  Statement: [Function: Statement],\r\n  DBPool: [Function: DBPool],\r\n  SQL_FALSE: 0,\r\n  SQL_TRUE: 1,\r\n  SQL_NTS: -3,\r\n  SQL_SQLSTATE_SIZE: 5,\r\n  ...\r\n}\r\n> require('idb-connector')\r\n{ dbconn: [Function: dbconn],\r\n  dbstmt: [Function: dbstmt],\r\n  SQL_FALSE: 0,\r\n  SQL_TRUE: 1,\r\n  SQL_NTS: -3,\r\n  SQL_SQLSTATE_SIZE: 5,\r\n}\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nWill open a PR with this patched",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2019-02-20T05:48:40Z",
                              "closedAt": "2019-02-20T17:06:04Z",
                              "lastComment": "",
                              "commentCount": 0
                         },

                         {
                              "title": "Error Handling",
                              "description": "**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/litmis/nodejs-idb-pconnector/issue/15) by me.**\n\n----------------------------------------\n\nNoticed a few Issues regarding error handling.\n\n1. Wth the aggregate functions I noticed that errors can be masked / swallowed while working within the async function.\n\n2. error.stack information missing.\n\n## Problem 1\n\nFor instance the runSql() example:\n\n```\nconst {DBPool} = require('idb-pconnector');\nconst pool = new DBPool({url: '*LOCAL'}, {debug: true});\nasync function runSqlExample(){\n  /*\n  * Directly execute a statement by providing the SQL to the runSql() function.\n  * NOTE: Stored Procedures must use the prepareExecute() method instead.\n  */\n try {\n\n   let result = await pool.runSql('blank');\n\n    if (result !== null) {\n     console.log(`\\n${JSON.stringify(result)}`);\n   } else{\n      console.log('Nothing to show');\n   }\n\n } catch (error){\n   console.log(`Error was: ${error.stack}`);\n }\n}\n\nrunSqlExample();\n\n```\nif debug is turned **off** the log will be:\n\n```\nNothing to show\n```\nEven though an error occurred and should have been caught in the catch block!\n\n\nIf debug is turned **on** the log is:\n```\nCreating Connection 0...\nConnection 0 created\nCreating Connection 1...\nConnection 1 created\nCreating Connection 2...\nConnection 2 created\nCreating Connection 3...\nConnection 3 created\nCreating Connection 4...\nConnection 4 created\nCreating Connection 5...\nConnection 5 created\nCreating Connection 6...\nConnection 6 created\nCreating Connection 7...\nConnection 7 created\nFinding available Connection...\nConnection 0 found\nExecuting SQL...\nSQL Statement: \n(node:143412) Warning: N-API is an experimental feature and could change at any time.\nSQLExecDirect(-1): \n\n **** ERROR *****\nSQLSTATE: 42617\nNative Error Code: -198\nSQL statement empty or blank. \nSQL Error: Error: SQLSTATE=42617 SQLCODE=-198 SQL statement empty or blank.\nRetiring Connection 0...\nSQLDisconnect: conn obj [180311650] handler [2]\nSQLFreeConnect: conn obj [180311650] handler [2]\nSQLFreeConnect[0]\nConnection 0 retired\nDetaching Connection 0...\nSQLFreeStmt: stmth 3 [SQL_DROP]\nSQLFreeStmt(-2)\nConnection 0 detached\nSQL did not return a result set.\nNothing to show\n```\n\nAn error occurs within the runSql() but it is not get sent up to runSqlExample() because it caught within runSql() and an error message is printed only if debug is turned **on**. Otherwise you would be returned `null` but not know an error occurred.\n\n```\n async runSql(sql = '') {\n    let me = this,\n      connection = me.attach(),\n      statement = connection.getStatement(),\n      resultSet = [];\n\n    try {\n      me.log(`Executing SQL...\\nSQL Statement: ${sql}`);\n      resultSet = await statement.exec(sql);\n      me.log(`Executed SQL`);\n    } catch (err) {\n      me.log(`SQL Error: ${err}`);\n      await me.retire(connection);\n    }\n    try {\n      await me.detach(connection);\n    } catch (error) {\n      await me.retire(connection);\n      console.log(`Connection Error: ${error}`);\n    }\n    if (!resultSet.length){\n      me.log('SQL did not return a result set.');\n      return null;\n    }\n    me.log(`Fetched Result Set`);\n    return resultSet;\n  }\n```\n\nErrors should be thrown when detected within runSql() instead of caught and swallowed, so that callers can be handle it accordingly.\n\nI think a better solution would be:\n\n```\n async runSql(sql = '') {\n    let me = this,\n      connection = me.attach(),\n      statement = connection.getStatement(),\n      resultSet = [];\n\n    try {\n      me.log(`Executing SQL...\\nSQL Statement: ${sql}`);\n      resultSet = await statement.exec(sql);\n      me.log(`Executed SQL`);\n    } catch (err) {\n      me.log(`SQL Error: ${err}`);\n      await me.retire(connection);\n      throw err;\n    }\n    try {\n      await me.detach(connection);\n    } catch (error) {\n      await me.retire(connection);\n      console.log(`Connection Error: ${error}`);\n      throw error;\n    }\n    if (!resultSet.length){\n      me.log('SQL did not return a result set.');\n      return null;\n    }\n    me.log(`Fetched Result Set`);\n    return resultSet;\n  }\n```\n\nNow running the same example from before with debug **off**\n\nlog\n\n```\nError was: Error: SQLSTATE=42617 SQLCODE=-198 SQL statement empty or blank.\n\n```\nNotice how the error was caught now but the stack the information was not provided?\n\n## Problem 2\n\nWithin [idb-pconnecor.js](https://bitbucket.org/litmis/nodejs-idb-pconnector/src/8586555b20ff99d3372c7309687891d91906890e/lib/idb-pconnector.js?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default#idb-pconnector.js-317) the `error` variable passed to the reject() is a Javascipt Error returned from `idb-connector` but it does not contain any stack info! \n\nSo to account for this I found two soultions either pass the reject() a new Error() which would create the stack at that moment or use [Error.captureStackTrace](https://nodejs.org/api/errors.html#errors_error_capturestacktrace_targetobject_constructoropt). I would prefer to just pass reject a new Error() with the message returned from the `error` variable.\n\n```\n  async exec(sqlString) {\n    let stmt = this.stmt;\n\n    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {\n      stmt.exec(sqlString, function (result, error){\n        if (error) {\n          reject(new Error(error.message));\n        } else {\n          resolve(result);\n        }\n      });\n    });\n  }\n```\n\nSo now lets run our example again:\n\nlog:\n\n```\nError was: Error: SQLSTATE=42617 SQLCODE=-198 SQL statement empty or blank.\n    at Object.<anonymous> (idb-pconnector.js:323:18)\n```\nSo now the stack was printed and pointed back to where the rejection occurred!\n\nWe can actually improve the stack trace by appending to it within the runSql():\n\n```\n async runSql(sql = '') {\n    let me = this,\n      connection = me.attach(),\n      statement = connection.getStatement(),\n      resultSet = [];\n\n    try {\n      me.log(`Executing SQL...\\nSQL Statement: ${sql}`);\n      resultSet = await statement.exec(sql);\n      me.log(`Executed SQL`);\n    } catch (err) {\n      me.log(`SQL Error: ${err}`);\n      await me.retire(connection);\n      const reason = Error('runSql(): Failed to exec() ');\n      reason.stack += `\\nCaused By:\\n ${err.stack}`;\n      throw reason;\n    }\n    try {\n      await me.detach(connection);\n    } catch (error) {\n      await me.retire(connection);\n      console.log(`Connection Error: ${error}`); \n      const reason = Error('runSql(): Failed to detach() the connection');\n      reason.stack += `\\nCaused By:\\n ${error.stack}`;\n      throw reason;\n    }\n    if (!resultSet.length){\n      me.log('SQL did not return a result set.');\n      return null;\n    }\n    me.log(`Fetched Result Set`);\n    return resultSet;\n  }\n\n```\n\nNow running the example the log is:\n\n```\nError was: Error: runSql: Failed to exec()\n    at DBPool.runSql (dbPool.js:354:22)\n    at <anonymous>\nCaused By:\n Error: SQLSTATE=42617 SQLCODE=-198 SQL statement empty or blank.\n    at Object.<anonymous> (idb-pconnector.js:323:18)\n\n```\nWhich is more detailed and easier to trace what went wrong.\n\nWe can also use .catch() within the aggregates instead of try catch blocks.\n\n```\n async runSql(sql = '') {\n    let me = this,\n      connection = me.attach(),\n      statement = connection.getStatement(),\n      resultSet = [];\n\n      me.log(`Executing SQL...\\nSQL Statement: ${sql}`);\n      resultSet = await statement.exec(sql).catch(async (err)  =>{\n        me.log(`SQL Error: ${err}`);\n        await me.detach(connection);\n        const reason = Error('runSql(): Failed to exec() ');\n        reason.stack += `\\nCaused By:\\n ${err.stack}`;\n        throw reason;\n    });\n\n      await me.detach(connection).catch(async (error) => {\n        await me.retire(connection);\n        console.log(`Connection Error: ${error}`); \n        const reason = Error('runSql(): Failed to detach() the connection');\n        reason.stack += `\\nCaused By:\\n ${error.stack}`;\n        throw reason;\n    });\n\n    if (!resultSet.length){\n      me.log('SQL did not return a result set.');\n      return null;\n    }\n    me.log(`Fetched Result Set`);\n    return resultSet;\n  }\n\n```\n## Solution 1\nwe use `reject( new Error(error.message) )` to obtain the stack info, also to update runSql & prepareExecute() to throw errors when they occur & use .catch() blocks.\n\n## Alternative Solution\n\nInstead of rejecting the promise (causes an error to be thrown) when we determine a problem , we could always resolve our promises with an object that contains: `error` & `result` property.That way we could always check the returned object if the error is set and deal with it accordingly. This might be a nicer approach than Solution 1.  \n\nThoughts @ThePrez @aaronbartell @brianmjerome\n",
                              "label": "bug",
                              "createdAt": "2018-10-08T17:19:29Z",
                              "closedAt": "2018-10-19T14:37:18Z",
                              "lastComment": "2019-01-22T17:05:36Z",
                              "commentCount": 2
                         },

cusshp char(3);\n  deldat char(8);\n  servloc char(2);\n  ordtype char(3);\n  prcwght char(7);\n  field char(50);\n  errflg char(1);\nend-pr;\ndcl-pi PGM1;\n  controlnumber char(50);\n  custno RPGLE\n  PARAMETER STYLE GENERAL WITH NULLS;\n```\n\nSample program\n\n```js\nconst db = require('idb-pconnector');\nconst pool = new db.DBPool({}, {debug: true });\n\nasync function invoke(){\n  let }\n}\n\ninvoke();\n```\n\nBelow are results. Maybe I am doing it wrong?\nWould you mind adding an example using the fetch() function which includes how to detect the end of the dataset?\n\nTo get our example to work:  I had to change the fetch() function to catch the return code from fetchSync() and reject the promise if <> 0...  \n\n\n```\n#!javascript\nasync fetch() {\n    let stmt = this.stmt;\n    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {\n     \n        let rc = stmt.fetchSync((result, error) => {\n          if (error) {\n            reject(error);\n          } else {\n           resolve(result);\n          }\n        });\n        if (rc !== 0) {\n          reject(rc);\n        }\n    });\n  }\n\n```\n",

Request(this, READ_OP, offset, size, null, cb))\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\n### 5 async-append-only-log\r\n\r\n```diff\r\n  function getBlock(offset, cb) {\r\n    const blockIndex = getBlockIndex(offset)\r\n\r\n    if (cache.has(blockIndex)) {\r\n      debug('getting offset %d from cache', offset)\r\n      const cachedBlockBuf = cache.get(blockIndex)\r\n      cb(null, cachedBlockBuf)\r\n    } else {\r\n      debug('getting offset %d from disc', offset)\r\n      const blockStart = getBlockStart(offset)\r\n-     raf.read(blockStart, blockSize, function onRAFReadDone(err, blockBuf) {\r\n        cache.set(blockIndex, blockBuf)\r\n        cb(err, blockBuf)\r\n      })\r\n    }\r\n  }\r\n```\r\n\r\n### 6 async-append-only-log\r\n\r\n```diff\r\n  function del(offset, cb) {\r\n    if (compaction) {\r\n      cb(delDuringCompactErr())\r\n      return\r\n    }\r\n    const blockIndex = getBlockIndex(offset)\r\n    if (blocksToBeWritten.has(blockIndex)) {\r\n      onDrain(function delAfterDrained() {\r\n        del(offset, cb)\r\n      })\r\n      return\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    if (blocksWithDeletables.has(blockIndex)) {\r\n      const blockBuf = blocksWithDeletables.get(blockIndex)\r\n      gotBlockForDelete(null, blockBuf)\r\n    } else {\r\n-     getBlock(offset, gotBlockForDelete)\r\n    }\r\n    function gotBlockForDelete(err, blockBuf) {\r\n      if (err) return cb(err)\r\n      const actualBlockBuf = blocksWithDeletables.get(blockIndex) || blockBuf\r\n      Record.overwriteWithZeroes(actualBlockBuf, getOffsetInBlock(offset))\r\n      deletedBytes += Record.readSize(actualBlockBuf, getOffsetInBlock(offset))\r\n      blocksWithDeletables.set(blockIndex, actualBlockBuf)\r\n      scheduleFlushDelete()\r\n      cb()\r\n    }\r\n  }\r\n```",

                              "title": "Crash writeWithFSync on a null block",
                              "description": "I am not sure exactly what triggered this crash but I'll document it as well as I can.\r\n\r\nI'm running AAOL 4.3.5 and jitdb 7.0.1 and ssb-db2 4.2.1 in Manyverse. Some 30s after app startup (and all other queries working as normally), in the middle of making several ssb-db2 `deleteFeed` calls (no compaction yet), I got this crash for the ~20th `deleteFeed` call:\r\n\r\n![Screenshot from 2022-08-03 11-46-12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90512/182566034-9a179a1a-65b7-4888-ae9b-e24572405646.png)\r\n\r\nThe lines of code are in random-access-storage v1.4.3:\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/random-access-storage/random-access-storage/blob/50dd02fd07d5d1690a3346684f8aac74dd76d017/index.js#L65\r\n\r\nand\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/ssbc/async-append-only-log/blob/24e6d487a058cd3b27c74eab3d478428f13a8745/index.js#L162\r\n\r\nwhich can only mean we tried to write a blockBuf that was `null` not a Buffer.
